Regina, December 14th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I presume that the Rt. Reverend Bishop Martin of Prince Albert will get in touch with our Department regarding the resignation of Mrs. Ida McLeod of the North Day School on the James Smith's Reserve.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
December 19, 1944.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Searth & Victoria, Regina,
Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, regarding the vacancy at the James Smith Day School, Bishop Martin has just written to us suggesting the temporary employment of Mrs. L. Ahenakew. He states that she has her Grade Eleven and is a bright, keen young woman and he feels would exert a very good influence with the Indian children. Her temporary appointment has been approved. If a qualified teacher can be obtained at any time Mrs. Ahenakew's services will cease. In any case it is not our intention to employ her longer than to June 30 next.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, February 2, 1945.

REGISTERED

N. J. McLeod, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

We are enclosing herewith cheque No. 48616, drawn in favour of I. Vandall, formerly teacher James Smith Indian Day School, in the amount of $102.13, being refund of Retirement Fund account.

L. W. McGutchison
Chief Treasury Officer.
Ottawa, July 6, 1945.

Dear Bishop Martin:

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, the Department approves the transfer of Mr. L. Ahenskew from the Fort a-la-Corne South School to the James Smith Indian Day School. Salary will be allowed him at the rate of $95.00 a teaching month. This transfer will be effective from September 1, 1945.

In view of your recommendation regarding this transfer, it is presumed that Mrs. Ahenskew gave up duties at the James Smith School on July 1, 1945.

Yours sincerely,

For Deputy Minister.

Right Rev. H.D. Martin, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.
Ottawa, July 6, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY,

Rev James Smith Indian Day School, No. 608.

Please note that Mrs. L. Ahenskew, who has been temporarily in charge of this school, gave up duties on July 1, 1945, and no further payment of salary should be made to her.

It has been decided to transfer Rev. L. Ahenskew from the Fort a-la-Corne South School (#603) to the James Smith School, effective September 1, 1945, at a salary of $35.00 a teaching month.

Please note that Mr. Ahenskew is a Treaty Indian and is teaching on an Indian reserve. Consequently, he is not liable for income tax.

I attach copy of letter approving this transfer.

For Deputy Minister.
Bishop
The Rt.Rev.Henry D.Martin, D.D.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I now wish to nominate Miss Mildred Hitchcock as teacher at the South School on Fort a la Corne Reserve. I have given Miss Hitchcock's qualifications in a previous letter, and I would like to add that she is most anxious to help in Indian work. I have every confidence that she would do good and faithful work on a reserve. I have not heard from you regarding the transfer of Mr. L. Ahenakew from the South School to the North School at Fort a la Corne and of course Miss Hitchcock's nomination is subject to your agreement of the proposed change.

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd.) Henry D. Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, July 17, 1945.

OTTAWA

Gentlemen:

Thanks for yours received today re Harvey Jacobs, R.R. #3 Thamesville.

Yes, I am aware that the Department is engaging teachers who take charge of Indian day schools. On my trip north a few years ago I happened to call at an Indian school at Fort a la Corne and was greatly pleased to meet the teacher, who was an Indian. From all I could hear round about she was a splendid teacher and was doing good work. I believe her husband, also an Indian, had one room and she had another, it being a two-roomed school if I remember correctly. What I found, however, was that they were badly in need of maps of various kinds, and I promised to send to that particular teacher, whose name I have forgotten, a series of maps. If she is still there you will likely know, and if so I would be glad to send her maps.

Yours faithfully,

JRM/P. John R. MacNicol.
Ottawa, November 23rd, 1945.

Dear Mr. MacNicol:

In reply to your letter of the 20th instant, the teacher who was in charge of the Fort-a-la-Corne a few years ago is no longer there. There are two schools at Fort-a-la-Corne, the North and the South. However, both teachers have been replaced, therefore, the teacher you refer to would not receive the maps were you to send any.

It is customary for teachers to send in a requisition to this office for supplies which they may require. This includes maps, books, stationery, etc. I, therefore, feel certain that since your visit these schools have requisitioned and received the material necessary to carry out their duties.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Mr. J.H. MacNicol,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ontario.
MARCH QUARTER REPORT.

Education

All day schools in this Agency have been open during the period covered by this report, attendance at a few schools has been irregular due to cold weather and the pupils' homes being situated at a distance from day school.

A lunch consisting of a hot drink of cocoa with health biscuits was supplied each pupil at mid-day.

With the advent of spring and warmer weather regular attendance will be insisted upon at all day schools.

H. J. McLeod,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 5, 1946.

Mr. H. J. McLeod, Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

I have just received Inspector Mahood's report regarding his inspection of the James Smith Indian Day School on May 17.

The Inspector states that the supply of books and equipment should be improved. In this connection I may say that we have not yet received the requisition from the teacher for the classroom supplies for the academic year 1946-47. This should have been forwarded some weeks ago in order to give us time to secure the articles that we supply.

The Inspector recommends window blinds, screens and a few pictures, to relieve the monotony of the room. You may arrange for the purchase of these.

It is stated, further, that the walls and ceilings of this classroom should be redecorated. If you consider this necessary, please submit an estimate of the cost.

Mr. Mahood states that the present teacher, Mr. Ahenakew, has much to his credit as a teacher. However, the Inspector considers that it would be to the benefit of Mr. Ahenakew and the pupils if he were transferred to some other school and a new teacher engaged. Please let me have your comments on this suggestion.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Reference is made to your letter No.109-4-1 regarding Inspector Mahood's report covering North Day School, James Smith Reserve.

In regards to his recommendations re. decorating classroom, window blinds, screens and a few pictures. The matter will receive my attention.

With reference to classroom supplies. Mr. Ahenakew has received all supplies requested by him and, it not satisfactory or sufficient, the fault lies directly on his shoulders.

I am pleased to report that, according to a communication I have received from the Rt. Rev. Bishop Henry D. Martin, Mr. Ahenakew does not intend to continue teaching on James Smith Reserve following termination of the present academic term and the services of a competent teacher are being sought by Bishop Martin for the ensuing term at the North Indian Day School on James Smith Reserve.

N.J. McLeod,
Indian Agent.
June 20, 1946.

Mr. N. J. McLeod, Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

Yours of 12 June refers to the intended resignation of Mr. Ahenakew as teacher of the James Smith Indian Day School (North).

Please ensure that his letter of resignation is forwarded to this office if he still intends to discontinue his teaching duties. We would also like to be informed as to the disposition of his funds in his Retirement Fund account.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The following report on the affairs of Duck Lake Sask Agency, covering the period 1st April to 30th April, 1946.

Education:

All day schools in this agency were open during the period covered by this report; reasonable satisfactory progress was noted, attendance fair, discipline fair. All day schools closed on June 28th, fo the annual holiday season.

The following Day School Teachers have handed in their resignations.

1. Mrs E.G. Carlin, Whitesap Moose Woods Sioux, Dundurn, Sask.
2. Mr. L. Ahenskew, James Smith Reserve North, Fort la Corne, Sask.

Replacement teachers will be required for commencement of the September 1st 1946 academic term.

N.J. McLeod,
Indian Agent.
To Whom It May Concern:

L-12835 (WO) CSM F.C. Dey.

This NCO has served with this Regiment continuously since April 1940 with the exception of time spent on courses.

He has been employed as an Orderly Room Clerk, Pay Clerk and Postal.

During the last eight months - January-August 1943 he has been Educational NCO for the Unit.

It will be seen that CSM Dey has occupied positions of trust and responsibility during his service with this Battalion. Performance of these duties has been entirely satisfactory. He has always had plenty of initiative and good judgment into heavy tasks he has undertaken.

He has our complete confidence.

I unhesitatingly recommend CSM Dey to anyone fortunate enough to receive his services.

This Unit repels the loss of CSM Dey because of his being selected for work in an active theatre of war.

F.A. Clift - Lt. Col.
O.P.S. SASK. R.C.A.O.

The following report on the affairs of Duck Lake, Sask. Indian Agency covering the period July 1st. to Sept. 30th, 1946 is respectfully submitted.

Education

All day schools in this Agency, except Moose Woods Sioux, re-opened on September 3rd for the ensuing academic term. Following the duties at James Smith North Day School.

To date the services of a teacher for Moose Woods Whitecap Sioux Day School has not been found and every effort is being made to locate a suitable teacher. Attendance at all Day Schools now open has shown a marked improvement. Parents of Indian children in attendance at Residential Schools and are insisting that their children attend Day Schools on their Reservations, with the results that the seating accommodation at all Indian Day Schools is taxed to the limit and in a few cases overcrowding has resulted.

Two Indian families of John Smith Band are sending their children to a white day school adjacent to their reservation. The reasons given by the parents are that they do not want their children associating with white children.

N. J. McLeod,
Indian Agent.
Duck Lake, Sask.

Reference is made to your letter dated November 20th., your file No. 109-4-1 (W.T.l.) regarding condition of the Teacher's Residence at North Day School on James Smith Indian Reserve.

With reference to the remarks of Bishop Martin quoted in your letter regarding the condition of teacher's residence being responsible for the resignation of Mr. Dey, I cannot agree with Bishop Martin's views. The teacher's residence is warm and clean, it is definitely not failing apart and furthermore Mr. Dey did not intimate to me that the condition of the residence had anything to do with resignation.

True the interior should be repair, old plaster removed and the interior replastered and furnace repaired or replaced with a new furnace. Cement cistern should be installed, fences repaired and school yard cleaned up, also all buildings painted on the exterior. However, I wish to make it clear that the premises and buildings are definitely not in an unhabitable condition.

The school building admittedly is too small to accommodate the number of Indian children in attendance. All of these matters were discussed by me with Mr. Dey and he is well aware of the fact that due to shortages of materials and skilled labour nothing can be done about the matter at present, especially during the cold weather months. It is my intention to have necessary buildings completed in the future and I have discussed with Mr. Dey future plans for proper buildings to be placed on James Smith Reserve for educational purposes.

Mr. Dey has never indicated to myself that the teacher's residence was entirely unsatisfactory and he is well aware of the fact that during the war years we were unable to carry out a building program.

I realize the difficulty Bishop Martin is confronted with in regards to securing the service of satisfactory Indian Day School teachers, in fact a shortage of qualified teachers is prevalent throughout this Province. However to lay the blame on our Department buildings is definitely not the solution to his problem and I can assure Bishop Martin a large number of outside teachers are living in hotels at so called tenements in white settlements in comparison with the teacherage at the North James Smith Reserve School.

I am definitely of the opinion that Bishop Martin is not aware of the reasons for Mr. Dey leaving and on my next visit to Prince Albert I will call and discuss the matter with him personally.

In the meantime I do not feel that it is wise to recommend any further expenditures in connection with the teacherage and School class room, as I am definitely of the opinion the only proper solution is to erect new buildings as and when materials and skilled labour become available.
No doubt equipping all Day School teacher's residence with proper furniture and kitchen equipment would be an inducement to qualified teachers assuming the duties, however I hesitate to recommend such expenditures as it would mean a large outlay not only now but in future years.

In conclusion allow me to state that the only solution to the problem, as I see it, in regard to securing the services of qualified teachers is to have all Indian day school teachers under the Civil Service Commission free from missionary services and hired directly by the officials of our Department. This method coupled with an upward revision of salaries would produce results.

The following sums have been expended in decorating and cleaning the North Day School and Teacher's Residence during the month of August 1946.

|----------------|-----------|--------|
| North Day School | 40.00     | 50.00  |

Dear Bishop Martin:

We have just received a letter from Mr. Indian Agent McLeod in which he states as follows:

"During the past week I contacted Mrs. Burbridge by telephone at her home at Ridgedale, Sask. She advises that due to severe winter weather and bad condition of all roads she will be unable to assume the duties at the North School on James Smith Reserve until the commencement of the Easter term on April 8th, next. Also the fact that she is now residing on a farm where a number of livestock are kept she will require time in order to wind up their affairs before moving to the school residence on James Smith Reserve.

I have agreed to this arrangement especially in view of her teaching qualifications. T.D.I forms and staff questionnaire have been forwarded to Mrs. Burbridge for completion and immediately she assumes the duties at James Smith School they will be forwarded to your office".

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

AIRMAL

Ottawa, October 1, 1947.

Dear Mr. Dey:

I have for answer your letter of September 22. I was pleased to hear that you are still interested in our Indian schools. I feel sure that there will be vacancies in British Columbia which might interest you. I have written today to Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C., and have asked him to let you know of any vacancies. I attach a copy of one of our new application forms which I suggest you have completed and sent to Major MacKay as soon as possible, so that he will be fully aware of your qualifications. If there are no vacancies which interest you, we will have two new day schools opening near Edmonton, Alberta, in November or December. If you will let me hear from you later, in the event you are not settled in B.C., then I will give you the details concerning these Alberta schools.

Sincerely yours,

Emel.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Frank G. Dey,
10 Beckman Block,
Kamloops, B.C.

Enclosed herewith please find Survey of Potential School Population on the James Smith Indian Reserve #100.

We now operate two Indian Day Schools on the James Smith Reserve and on checking over the enclosed form listing potential school population, it would appear that the solution to providing additional class room facilities would be as follows:

1. Erect a new combined teachers residence and class room in a suitable location approximately five miles distance from our present day school buildings.

2. Repair the South Day School and teachers residence and continue to operate this particular school where it is now located.

3. Repair and erect an addition to the North Day School, by extending the building approximately 16' to 20' in length.

In this manner we will have provided three day schools located on the James Smith Indian Reserve in areas adjacent to Indian settlements thereon.

Re: James Smith North Day School (605)

Provisions are being made in our 1950-51 estimates for finances to cover costs of enlarging class room accommodation at this school.

Two day schools are now on this particular Indian Reserve, one located near the north end of the Reserve and close to Department farm buildings; the other located seven miles south and towards the south end of James Smith Reserve. The Indians homes located on this particular Reserve are scattered over an area of approximately sixty square miles, with the highest number adjacent to the area served by the north day school with the results that the class room at this particular day school is overcrowded. Whereas, an increased attendance could be accommodated at the south day school, however, this is doubtful as 29 pupils are now available.

The following shows the number of school age pupils and under school age children of James Smith Band:

| School Age | Under School Age |
|------------|------------------|
| Area North School - 42 | 65 |
| Area South School - 29 | 65 |
| Total | 71 |

To overcome the difficulty here on James Smith Reserve in connection with providing additional accommodation is a problem that requires careful thought with an eye towards the future.

The farming area of James Smith Reserve all lies towards the southern part of the Reservation, however, at present the wooded area from which supplies of fuel wood is available to our Indians therein lies towards the north, with the results that I believe our Indians will reside in greater numbers in the future towards the wooded area.

In view of the foregoing I believe we should increase class room accommodation at the north day school and move the south day school and teacher's residence approximately one mile west and one mile north from its present location moving the south day school will provide for an increase slightly in attendance and possibly absorb a few children of school age now in attendance at the north school. This move will also place the buildings in a more central part of the southern end of the Reserve and at the same time place the buildings adjacent to good water supplies. I might add here that water supplies are not available at the present site of the south school and water for use of teacher and school is being hauled a distance of approximately two miles.
I therefore recommend that consideration be given to enlarging the class room at the north day school by additions to the present building or by erection of a new two room day school at this location. I might add that the present school building at the north is old and will require considerable repairing in the near future. It is of log construction and sheated outside and inside.

W. J. McLeod

In conversation with Miss Jean McKay, Prince Albert, the other day her correspondence with you, with regard to our pre-mission tests, was referred to. I suggested to her that, since I was more familiar with the situation leading up to this correspondence, it might be well for me to write to you in the matter in order that any misunderstanding might be readily smoothed out.

May I refer to the organization under whose guidance our premission tests are arranged? Three inspectorates combine in the scheme; namely, Kinistino, Shell Lake, and Prince Albert. Our Examination Board consists of the three inspectors, a representative from each of the three Inspectorial Teachers' Associations, and one from the city schools of Prince Albert. Miss Jean McKay is the secretary of this board. As I have intimated, the test papers are prepared under the direction of this board. A test paper for each subject is provided to each pupil in a school. For this service each school board contributes the sum of $2.00 for each room in the school. I must point out that the tremendous burden of work that this service imposes can be carried only if the trustees cooperate freely, as they did in the past, and that the burden is carried by those who use the service to teachers and pupils is of utmost importance.

Some of the Indian schools have been receiving this service mainly these schools in the Shell Lake inspectorate. The plan has followed that for our secretary to send an invoice in June, I think, to the Agent on the basis of $2.00 per room, for the year. We inspectors... (text not legible) and that this was the regular course to follow, and I submitted to our secretary advise each Agent accordingly for these schools which have a good-sized enrolment in the middle and upper grades.

The Indian school teachers have been themselves purchasing a set of papers, that is, one copy of each test in each subject for all grades. This has cost them $1.00. Some of these teachers have been obtaining papers from neighboring rural schools, but this is not satisfactory, as perhaps the main value of the papers is the information they give of the curriculum as a guide to the teacher for the following year. I should think that one set of the papers would be sufficient for such a school as that on the John Smith Reserve, as there are few pupils above the primary grades. I know that Mr. Waite would much like to have this service.

I hope that this explanation will make the situation clear, and we may look forward to your cooperation in the matter of the schools under your jurisdiction.

Sir:

The Department has received the enclosed accounts in connection with work done at the Fort a la Corne South and James Smith's Indian Day Schools.

Apparently you have paid this man fifty cents an hour for his work, which seems to be a reasonable amount to allow, and for this reason the Department cannot understand why you submitted vouchers for his meals. The vouchers for the work cover so many hours, and it is impossible from the information given on them to know how many days the man was employed. As a result, we do not know whether one meal a day was supplied to him or more than one.

I may say that this a new method of engaging labour, viz., so much an hour, plus meals, and, due to present regulations, it is impossible for the Department to consider payment of the accounts in the manner in which they have been presented. They are, therefore, being returned, in order that you may give full explanations regarding the reasons for authorizing work in the manner in which it has been done.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Re: Inspectorial Promotion Tests in Indian Schools

For two or three years past some, I think, most of the Indian day schools in the Prince Albert, Kinistino, and Shell Lake inspectorates have made use of the promotion tests prepared for these three inspectorates. In some instances there appears to have been some difficulty in getting the requisition approved for their payment. I would refer to the letter of your Department under date of April 29, 1935, to Mr. G.P. Schmidt, Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Sask., a copy of which was forwarded to me.

Two of three of the teachers of Indian Day Schools in this vicinity have again expressed their desire to have the promotion tests this year. I, therefore, thought best to lay the whole situation before you, as suggested by the examination board, in the hope that the matter might be cleared up once for all.

May I refer to the organization under whose direction and guidance our promotion tests are arranged? Three inspectorates, viz., Prince Albert, Kinistino, and Shell Lake, combine in the scheme. Our examination board consists of: the three inspectors, the president of each of the three inspectorates' teachers' associations, and one from the Principals' Association of the city of Prince Albert. The preparation of these papers, as you will appreciate, involves a tremendous amount of labour, which is done gratis. Expense is involved in printing the question papers and in clerical work in their distribution. The service to schools consists in supplying each pupil with a separate paper for each subject, that is for pupils above Grade III, and for about half of the subjects in Grades II and III. For this service a charge of $2 per school or room has been found to balance our books satisfactorily.

As I have indicated some of the Indian schools have been receiving and appreciating this service. I think some of the teachers have been paying for the material themselves. Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that owing to smoke escaping from a chimney fire in the teacher's residence of Fort-a-la-Corne North Day School, the kitchen walls and ceiling are blackened therefrom.

The chimney fire was apparently caused through the chimney having a faulty draft which creates creosote to accumulate and then catch on fire.

While I was visiting this reserve on the 7th instance, I instructed Mr. Jones, Farming Instructor, to have the chimney repaired.

Departmental letter # 109-4-5 October 6/37 authorizes an expenditure of $66.00 to repair the furnace in this building. It is expected that there will be a small surplus left which would be sufficient to cover the cost of the minor repair to the chimney. I beg to request authority to use it for that purpose.

I recommend that authority be granted to purchase 3 packets of kalsomine and one kalsomine brush for the purpose of kalsomining the kitchen mentioned, at a cost not exceeding $4.00.

Duck Lake, Saskatchewan,
February 20, 1939

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that Mr. W. A. Richford, Teacher at the Fort a la Corne North Day School, has requested to be supplied with the items as listed on the attached form No. 37, in triplicate.

The lock on the children's dining room is broken beyond repair. Four inside-door-locks in the Teacher's residence are broken off and the doors cannot be kept closed. These locks were broken off a number of years ago.

The water and refuse pail is required to replace those that have been in use in the children's dining room and are now worn out.

The water fountain in the school is rusted through and is of no further use. A stoneware crock could be used to replace it at less cost than a new fountain.

I recommend that the items requested be supplied.

Yours very truly,

S. H. SIMPSON,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo with reference to painting and repairs at the Fort a la Corne North Indian day school.

In the current year's appropriation it was only found possible to include the amount of $300.00 for repairs, improvements and new equipment at the schools in the Duck Lake Agency. We have already authorized expenditures of approximately $172.00. This leaves a balance of $128.00 still available.

If all the work requested for the Fort a la Corne North school were done the amount available would be considerably exceeded. Owing to the present setup of our appropriation this is not possible to consider.

You may purchase the 6 screen windows and arrange for the repairs to the fence at a total cost for material and labour of $19.15.

With regard to the painting it is considered that owing to lack of funds you should only do the interior painting this year. In view of the fact that this work will have to be done at once in order to have it ready before the school re-opens after the summer holidays you may arrange for local purchase, from firms on the approved list, the quantity of paint required for the interior painting of the school and teacher's residence if you consider that this is necessary. It is understood from your letter that Indian labour only will be employed to do this painting.

Yours truly,

S. H. Simpson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re: Estimates 1940-41.

I beg to enclose herewith Form No. 37 in triplicate listing materials required for repairing the Fort a la Corne North Day School buildings.

School Class Room:

The interior of this room is badly in need of being re-painted and kalsomined. Authority was granted by Departmental letter #102-4-5, dated August 8th, 1939 to have this work done if it was possible to arrange to do so before the school re-opened after the summer holidays. Owing to the only Indians capable of doing this work being otherwise employed it was not possible to have it done.

Dear Sir,

I am writing your office again after an interval of four years in the matter of providing Promotion Guide material for the Indian schools in this area. In this connection I would refer to your letter to me under date of May 21, 1936, and of June 13, 1936. I would also request that my letter to your Department of May 16, 1936, be read in considering this matter.

In the intervening years some misunderstanding has arisen in the case of some schools. I think with the change of teachers in some schools has been the main cause. It is possible, too, that the Agents of the Department, concerned, have either forgotten your Department's instruction of four years ago or interpreted your instructions to apply only to the one year, 1936.

The school inspectors (now superintendents) concerned in conference recently expressed themselves strongly as to the value of this material in their supervisory services to the schools, concerning which I wrote on May 16, 1936. As president of the organization for the preparation of this material I was requested to write your office and petition for your approval to the Indian agents for its purchase. It seems to me that as to whether it is really needed in a particular school is one that should concern the individual teacher and the superintendent. The enrolment varies and it is evident that with pupils in grades I and II only this service is not so vital. Might I respectfully suggest that your office write the two agents concerned instructing them to approve the purchase of this material should the teacher request it. Perhaps it is too much to suggest that your instructions be so worded that we need not have to approach your Department in the matter again.

Dear Sir,

With reference to Departmental letter No. 109-4-5 dated the 12th instant pertaining to glass and putty for the school and teacher's residence on the James Smiths Reserve, I beg to report as follows:

I am advised by Mr. W.A. Richford, teacher, that since he has been in charge of this school as from September 1st., 1938, one glass at the school was accidentally broken by a foot ball and two were broken at the teacher's residence owing to a storm window being blown off in a high wind. Fort a la Corne North Day School - School House - $86.00

In the 1944-45 Estimates, Duck Lake Agency, a request was made for interior decorations of the teachers' residence, at John Smith's Reserve, Moose Woods Sioux Reserve, James Smith Reserve, and Kinistino Reserve.

I would recommend that these be approved of and granted. Mr. Simpson, the Agency, states that with respect to the interior decorations at the John Smith Day School, and floors in the dining room and hall way are badly worn and in the first place there is only a one-ply lumber. There is sufficient experienced Indian labour on the reserve to do the work.

The Agent also request that if funds are available outside repairs be made to the Fort a La Corne North Indian Day School. This building is in bad need of re-painting. I also notice that the South School on the same reserve could do with a re-painting but at the present time it is in better shape than the school north of it.

With reference to 1945-46 Estimates Vote 76-02-221, sheet 76221; Provisions and supplies for Day School Mid Day meals amount $260.00.

As Family Allowances are now payable to Indians I believe the mid-day meals can be dispensed with and as a substitute a hot drink of cocoa supplied during the cold weather months only. However, before requesting for authority to make any expenditures for mid-day meals I would appreciate having your ruling as to what is considered the proper procedure to follow.

Since the opening of day schools on September, 2nd I have visited all Day Schools in this Agency and have requested the day school teachers to have a meeting of the Indian women and discuss this problem with them and at the same time prepare a sample lunch as a demonstration for their future guidance in preparing lunches for their children's mid-day meal while attending day school.

N.J. McLeod,
A/Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 18th September, 1945.

Mr. N.J. McLeod, Acting Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Sask.

I have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to mid-day meals supplied at Day Schools in the Duck Lake Agency. As you state, the Department feels that in view of the payment of Family Allowances, it can reasonably be expected that Indian children should receive better meals and the parents should be able to provide them with better lunches than in the past.

We have no intention of totally refusing some assistance towards the mid-day lunch at some schools but we feel in future our assistance should be confined to serving a hot drink plus the special biscuit which has been prepared under the direction of the Medical Services. We have already ordered the following quantity of biscuits for schools in your agency and it is expected they will arrive shortly:

- James Smith Day School: 450 lbs.
- John Smith: 300 lbs.
- Fort a la Corne: 400 lbs.
- Kinistino Day School: 600 lbs.

If you consider it necessary you can shift the quantity of biscuits in any way you consider advisable.

Authority is granted for the purchase of cocoa and milk required to serve a hot drink during the winter months at the four schools in your agency.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

XX XX XX

Education:

All Day Schools in this Agency are open and under the charge of competent teachers with the exception of James Smith South Day School. Miss M. Hitchcock assumed the teaching duties on September 1st, 1945, and according to the Public School Inspector's report she is not in possession of a teacher's certificate.

Attendance at all Day Schools is satisfactory and shows a marked improvement over previous years. This is due to Family Allowance regulations.

A lunch consisting of a hot drink, cocoa, and health biscuits is supplied to the pupils at mid-day during the cold winter months.

At Knistino Reserve the children are conveyed to and from the school each day by an Indian who is paid a small sum for his services from Family Allowance income by the parents of the children in attendance.

XX XX XX

BUILDINGS AND PREMISES

Building - Frame - Satisfactory affair.
Schoolroom - 24'x16'x11' - Windows - 6 (two rear and 4 at pupils' side). Body of light came from south. There are no blinds. Our sunshine days conditions as well as unhealthy. Curtains and blinds should be provided. Heating and ventilation are satisfactory.

Floor - Clean at times of visit. Recently scrubbed. Provisions made for new boys only are in 3 months. Properly school boards or other schools think that the health and education of their children demand that school be scrubbed at least twice a month. The Indian school should be scrubbed at least once a month.

Closets - Both uncleaned - Carpets not satisfactory condition. Boys' rooms are uncleaned. A polished trough, feeding & drinking in which animals should be installed.

Should have flag and flagstaff like other ones. (We should have an electricity line.)

GENERAL REMARKS

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

1. Grading under "Inspector's Examination" unsatisfactory. Pupils are young and deficient. Percentages given are uncertain determination of standards. An offer statement from inspectors as to how school is functioning in preparing Indians for living would be more to the point, would be more stimulatory to the teacher, call for views from the inspector and yield true information to the department. Why not use the regular reports forms of this province sending Trustees Report to Indian agent.

2. Management of work is generally satisfactory. Reading and language both oral and written should receive most prominent attention. The library should be better supplied with reading matter suitable to these children. I have commented the efforts to train habits of caution and cleanliness also the utmost taken in household science generally. This I believe should be an important part of the work. The great function of this school should be the setting up of these ideals, the establishment of these attitudes and the forming of these habits that make for success in life. These are the abiding things woven into the fabric of the character of the individuals that stick and influence long after information may be forgotten. There also are the things that come only with the good teacher and can not be measured with a yard stick and definitely reported in percentages. Your teacher I think is well endowed by nature to give such training.

3. Salary of teacher is too low to hold the good man. It is a little better than half the average salary in this province.

REMARKS RELATIVE TO THE EXAMINATION OF THE PUPILS

Attendance very irregular and unpunctual. No school can do its best work under such circumstances. Considering this the school has made fairly satisfactory progress. While the advance is not great it is real and in the right direction and indicates a force at work and the inertia overcome. Standing of grades is not generally on a par with that of corresponding grades of public schools of my Inspectorate. This I think cannot be expected. The average intelligence is probably lower. Standing in reading only fair; writing and spelling above average; language written and spoken poor; arithmetic fair. Reading and language should be stressed and should be based on material that appeals to interest of child.

The supply of books and equipment at this school has not noticeably improved since my last visit a year ago. The classroom library is practically non-existent and the small number of books which are available for the teacher are not sufficient in number to allow each pupil copies. The room lacks a clock, a globe, supplementary materials, a musical instrument of any kind (guitar, radio, gramophone). If instruction is to be improved equipment of this kind will have to be provided. New desks have been installed but the larger part of the desk equipment is of the old double type. The walls and floors of the classrooms are moderately clean and show evidence of care on the part of those responsible for the upkeep of the building. However, window blinds, screens, and a few pictures to relieve the monotony of the room would be of great value in improving the room. Walls and ceiling of the classrooms should be redecorated this summer. The suggestion that a new floor be laid is a good one; failing this, the present floor should be painted.

Premises are neat and clean. The playground swings need repair and new ropes. The exterior of both school and teachers' house could stand painting in the near future.

Instruction at the school could be considerably improved by securing the books and equipment already listed. It is felt that greater interest in reading would be brought about if reading corners of good quality were provided and if the teacher in charge made use of more progressive procedures. Small reading of the pupils should be of more purposeful nature and should be combined with an effort to make the reading materials more meaningful and more interesting to the pupils. In the handling of the children, also, more attention should be given to making the classrooms an interesting and enjoyable place in which democracy is practised and in which children are encouraged to develop initiative and independence. A wiser handling of the children in the classrooms should be combined with playground supervision so that through organized games and athletic activities a better pupil-teacher relationship will be established. A health and cleanliness program might be instituted in which the children are encouraged towards greater cleanliness and towards the practice of better health habits.

General comment: The condition of the North school appears to be generally fair with a few exceptions. The blackboards and floor are poor; the furnace needs repairs. The work of the school is progressing satisfactorily. Mrs. Burbridge is giving her best both as teacher and as a social worker. Her age and illness however, handicap her to some extent. There has been some trouble in discipline but I believe that the matter has now been settled and things are running smoothly. In the future I feel that more practical projects of the time could be devoted to Arts and Handicrafts; Indian children in other schools seem to do very good work and I feel that these should be stressed in both of the day schools. Music and physical education need to be made a part of their school lives. Practical Health Education is very essential in the lives of the pupils and perhaps this could be stressed.

General Comment:

The present school grounds are hardly large enough to provide good play space. It is definitely not large enough for a good softball diamond. When the new school is completed care should be taken to clear and level a good sized yard for this purpose.

It appears that children living on the reserve are only entered in the register if they attend school. I feel that a record should be kept of all children whether they attend or not; perhaps they could be listed in some other portion of the register. I also feel that a revision of the registers in Indian schools is needed. No provision is made for the age of a child or for the number of days he attended in each grade. When a child is promoted during the course of the year the date of such promotion should be recorded. At present this is not done.

A good assortment of library books has been received during the year. I am happy to be able to say that the condition of the library is showing improvement. The teacher has a set of the World Book Encyclopedia (1922 Edition) in the school. While the set is a good one, it is nevertheless too old to be of much value. I feel that a basic reference library is essential and a good set of reference books be provided without having to deduct the books from the library quota.

Supplementary readers are needed so that when the children finish their basic readers they can continue the reading program without "going over the reader again". You will realize, I am sure, that it is hard to maintain reading interest by repeating. Supplementary readers are needed for all grades from 1 to 4, one copy for each child. The new Work-Play series is recommended. (MacMillan Publishing Co.)

Progress in Grade 1 appears to be slow. The teacher states that it generally takes two years' school for a child to complete grade one. Grade 2 shows fairly good progress. Other grades are doing average work. I feel that Mrs. Burbridge is giving fairly satisfactory service at the present time.

It is recommended that a school radio be provided. The school broadcasts are becoming increasingly better and more stimulating. I have seen wonders in Art and Music by using the radio in the classroom.

General Comment:
The outstanding feature about this school is that it is very overcrowded.
This, together with the fact that ventilation is practically nonexistent except for opening the door, makes conditions rather unhealthy. It is urgently recommended that a new school be built either on this or on another location to take care of the needs of the children on this reserve.

The supplies appear to be adequate with the exception of Art and Handicraft materials. I am given to understand that ½ lb of plasticine or modelling clay is supplied to pupils in Grade 1. I suggest that this is of no value whatever. Any quantity less than 1 lb per pupil is ridiculous. I also suggest that the supply be not restricted to grade 1, but be supplied to the primary grades. I would also suggest that tempera paint be supplied to grades below Gr. 1. Creative art should be developed from the time the child starts school, and I do not believe that it is wise to restrict the lower grades to the use of crayons alone. They should be permitted to use tempera at an early age, and they should have large brushes, large sheets of paper, and an adequate supply of tempera powder. Four assorted callers, (four 1 lb cartons, I assume) will not last during the year if used to the extent that they should be used.

Mrs. Burbridge has taken a summer school class this year, which is very commendable. I believe she has skill as a teacher but there is slackness in some respects. The bell is not rung punctually at all times. Assignments are not corrected promptly. There is a general weakness in language in all grades, but especially in the lower grades. In some instances parent-teacher relationship is not very good. One boy was out of school for a year as a result of a problem in discipline and a lack of understanding between parent and teacher.

Attendance in the upper grades is good. From any observations I have made it would appear that the average Indian child can progress as well in school as the average white child if given the same opportunity and healthful, stimulating environment. It would seem, however, that the Indian schools are not able to secure the best teachers. Something should be done to make the Indian schools attractive enough for teachers to be happy in their surroundings. This would, I am sure, result in better Education for the Indian.

John Estek,

Dear Sir,

Your letter No. 253341/1, dated March 26th duly to hand.

I need not tell you how grateful I am, not only for the increase of salary, but also for the encouraging remarks you make concerning my school. It will greatly add to renewed energy and stimulus in my work during the school year upon which we have just entered.

The welfare of the Indians; the desire to raise them both morally and physically to a higher standard in life, has been my one aim during the whole time they have been under my care.

To bring this about, I soon became aware that my work would be of a more extensive nature than just a school teacher of the children.

While looking forward to the future generation for great results of my work among the children, at the same time it became quite apparent that unless I could raise the tone of the parents' lives too, my efforts among the children would be partly lost.

Therefore, while ministering to the educational wants of the children, it has always been my endeavor to elevate the parent with the child. It was not an easy attainment.
to achieve, for the Indians themselves were of the very "raw material."
The work has been very uphill, and discouragements have arisen time and time again.
But, with God-given strength I have kept on, and the reward is beginning to show itself.

Regarding the enrolment at my school, which you say "is not so large as it should be," I would like to state that I have every possible child of school-age on the Register.
Indeed, I have even brought in several children under school-age, as well as retained the over-age scholars, in order to get a good average.
I often wish there were more children in this band, that I could then get a larger enrolment.
I notice in your letter that you refer to this school as "Fort a la Corne Indian Day School."
This is not exactly correct, as there is a school of that name, at Fort a la Corne, proper, 10 miles from here.
My school is known as the South Fort a la Corne School.

From the very commencement of my work here, it has always been my endeavor to make the children's school life as attractive and interesting as I possibly could.
Knowing that the maintenance of the child's interest...
interest is the first step to education. I have sought by all possible means to arouse and keep up this interest.

The mastering of the "three R's" is always uninteresting work for children, if taken almost exclusively. The interest of Indian children especially soon tires.

Consequently I have introduced many varied subjects, in addition to those laid down as the code of work for Indian scholars.

Kindergarten have I specially taken up; finding my own material, and sparing no pains to add a little pleasure into the lives of the little ones under my care.

Drawing and singing, both of which the Indians are very fond, are two other subjects in which they have achieved wonderful success.

Musical Drills, such as the "hoop drill" and "stave drill" are also indulged in at such times as their interest for other work seems to be lagging.

As a further inducement to the scholars to attend school, for the last five years we have had a small school garden. I paid an Indian for turning up the sod, and each child who cares to go to the trouble of breaking up and preparing the soil, is furnished with a little plot to itself, and supplied with various vegetable seeds, which, when grown to ripeness becomes its own property.

With the different seasons of the year, different means have to be adopted to arouse fresh interest, without which latter there would
would be the tendency to drop off school attendance all together.

For the last three years I have encouraged my older scholars to enter into the Competition at the local Fair.

In the year 1905 my school gained a Diploma (which we now have framed on the school wall) from the Winnipeg Exhibition, for a general exhibit.

Last Fall they entered, with white children, in the Scholars Competitions at the Manitoba Agricultural Fair, and my school carried away eleven prizes out of twelve.

This was a great encouragement to them, as it meant cash for each prize winner to spend as it liked at Christmas.

Each of the two previous years they gained a special prize for general Indian schoolwork, which prize money was spent in giving the scholars a little party and presents at Christmas.

Also, as a further inducement to attend school, I have offered, for the last two years, book prizes twice yearly to the two children who come first and second in total attendance.

During the winter months, I also make hot soup for the children's mid-day meal. This latter is very much appreciated.

Considering all the inducements I have held out to them to attend school regularly, the result has not been so gratifying as I was ambitious for it to be.

This only goes to show how poor a chance a school would have, which possesses a teacher who was not enthusiastic for her or his scholars.
scholars, or who had no resourceful power to interest the scholars while they were at school.

If I may be allowed to say so, I think the present system of allowing the parents to take their children with them on all their hunting trips etc., is answerable to a great extent for the poor yearly average in most of the Indian Day Schools.

Under the present conditions, the children are bound to go with their parents, because it would be unreasonable to expect children to remain in their homes alone.

This difficulty might be overcome by the erection of a building, in which the teacher could house and keep them during such times as the parents were obliged to be away.

The supplying of the children with food, would be a great inducement to the parents to leave them behind.

Since you ask me to suggest, too, any means that may be adopted to stir up the interest of the parents to induce them to send them to school regularly, might I suggest that, at Treaty time, the parents of such children who had made a certain percentage of attendance at school during the past year, receive as a reward, so much extra cash for each such child. (The percentage to be fixed by the Inspector)

I wonder whether, too, when the trails are almost impassable in the winter with snow, and in the early spring with water, whether some reliable person could be deputed and paid...
paid for fetching the children to school, by sleigh or waggon as the case may be.

Where the children live two or more miles from the school this is specially needed, and never more so than it has been this past winter. Just now, too, the roads are swimming with water, and all the scholars are suffering from very severe coughs and colds.

Consequently, school at present is very badly attended. Had it have been possible to get the children to school without getting their feet soaking wet, as they have been, these coughs and colds would not have been so prevalent, and the school attendance would have been so much better.

The Farm Instructor's residence is 10 miles from here; so that it is impossible for him to take up this work here, as well as at Fort la Corne.

Regarding the improvements in the home life of the Indians, I think the root of my success lies in the fact that I, being a married woman, have my own home and family right amongst them; and every condition and phase in my home, acts as an incentive and copy for them to imitate, and to do likewise.

While not allowing any undue familiarity, I have kept my house open for them to visit, just as they felt the wish or necessity. If they have come for any special purpose, or in any need of help, I have always been ready to aid them, even to the sacrifice of...
of my own self, providing I could see the ultimate end would be their own enlightenment and uplifting.

Although not forcing it upon them, I have endeavored to make my own life and home a pattern of what I would like theirs to be. Knowing that the home depends largely upon what the woman makes it, I have specially tried to train my girl scholars in household management, both in school and in my own home, and have encouraged them to do the same in theirs. Especially in cases of sickness have I tried to help them, not only in nursing them in disease, but teaching them how to prevent disease to a great extent.

The management and rearing of their babies has been my chief phase of nursing, and in cases of sickness I have held myself ready at all hours to go to their aid. Indeed so great is the Indian respect and faith for this part of my work, that I am frequently being fetched to sick babies in the Fort or some part of the band, 10 miles north.

Never once have I allowed myself to become too familiar with them, but at the same time I have never let them feel that I put myself above them in any way; and, as long as they do not forfeit the honor, have always treated them with the respect that I expect them to treat me and mine, and indeed anyone in authority with whom they come in contact.

Before closing, I would like to add, that...
while putting myself up as a pattern to them,
I have endeavored to keep before my own
mind the example of Christ, who pleased not
himself; and thus, have tried to make my
service for the Master, the ground work of
the whole.

I trust the above will give a little insight
into my work here. If there is anything
I have not made quite plain, or any point
which may occur to you, that you would
like made clear, I will endeavor to explain,
if you care to write further to me.

I remain
Yours obediently

Dear Sir,- I wish to tender you the resignation of my duties as teacher at the South Fort a la Cerne School, which I ask you to kindly forward to the Indian Department at headquarters, as I desire to give the required three months notice, dating from Dec.31, 1909, to leave on March 31, 1910.

I have two strong reasons for wishing to leave. The chief is, that I think the Indian Department is not treating me quite fairly as compared with their attitude towards the teacher of Fort a la Cerne school. In the first place my salary is very much smaller than hers, although I have previously given five of the best years of my life to the interests of the Indians here, and to the Indian Department, on a very little wage, viz $300.00, barely enough to keep body and soul together, considering the isolation of the place and the fact that for a long time we had to pay out so much of it to the Indians in order to get them to do the slightest thing for us. We even had to pay them a dollar ($1.00) freightage on every sack of flour we asked them to bring up for us from our nearest town. I tell you this to bear out my statement as to its being a starvation wage. You, yourself, Mr. Macarthur, will quite bear me out that my work here has been very strenuous, too strenuous to bear, had it not been for the fact, that through it all I could see nothing but good resulting from my labors. I will ask you to compare the Bighead Indians of 1903 and of the present time. Their improvement has been the one main reason for the continuance of my work. During the past few months great changes have been commenced in the two Indian schools here; changes which have been brought about as the result of my success here and which were suggested to the Indian Department by Mr. Godfrey and myself; but it seems to me, we have only placed the "plums in the pie" for other people to pick out. Do not think I am writing this in any jealous spirit, for nothing would be
be farther from the truth. Knowing from experience how hard INK Indian School teaching is, I maintain that Miss Hawley is, no doubt worth all the money she gets, and no one could be more glad than I that the La Corne Indians have got a promising teacher at last. But the point I wish to bring forward is, that if she is worth it, then surely so am I, especially considering the advantages she has in regard to nearness and help of Farm Instructor, and which I have had to do without. In what respect she is more worthy than I, I fail to see. Certainly as regards my work as school teacher my worth is shown by results. Disregarding all Government Examination reports, I can show for the six years I have served here, Two Diplomas and One Silver Medal gained by my school. These will stand as a monument for all time as to the efficacy of my teaching among the Indian scholars at South Port a la Corne School. And this from children who, when I first came here knew so little English, that they did not know that a cat bore the name of cat in English; they only knew its Cree name. Next, as regards my nursing and dispensing work. The fact (which you yourself can verify) that only a very small proportion of times in all the years I have been here, have the Department been called upon to pay special doctor's fees for the Indians of this end of the reserve, speaks for itself. When I mention the fact we very rarely see the doctor here, it bears out still more forcibly the amount of work I have necessarily had to do in this line. The last time Dr. Hawke visited South Port a la Corne officially, to my knowledge, was on Sep.3. I spoke to him then, and asked him to look at the eyes of a child who was going blind, and whose mother was already blind. He said he would be down again on the 10th. of the month, and he would look at the child then. If he made a visit on that date, it was not to this end of the reserve; and I saw nothing of him from Sep.3. until Dec.13. when he found himself accidently here, having lost his way to Port a la Corne. Mr. Geoffrey asked him to look at the feet of an Indian, who, presumably was suffering from Tuberculosis of the bone, and whose feet was in a very bad way. "He could not stop" he said, to do that, or anything else; and
and that is about all the good the doctor is to us. The work all falls upon me. I think this will serve to show how much I do both as teacher and nurse. Then as regards her nearness to the farm Instructor, you can but grant this lessens her labour considerably.

When you consider the fact that we are 9 or 10 miles from Fort la Corne where the Farm Instructor is living, and the we (myself husband and family) are 12 to 14 miles from the nearest store, you will recall how isolated we are, and how necessarily a vast amount of work has fallen to me that I ought not to have had to do, or else it was left for my husband to do, who has received no pay nor no recognition. Miss Hawley's responsibility ends with her teaching and nursing; but my responsibility is endless, as the Indians here have no one else to depend upon. They come to me to help them in all their difficulties. In other words I have to be farm instructor, teacher, nurse, minister, gardener, seamstress, blacksmith, cook, and general arbitrator and justice of the Peace at all times.

I am just now preparing to have my Christmas tree at the school. It is dated for Dec. 29th. It is rather late, but unavoidably so, as I did not get your letter until Dec. 21st, to say that it was even settled that we were to have a Christmas tree here. Considering that the Christmas trees at both schools were given on the Success of Bighead School in the various exhibitions, we thought it hardly fair that theirs should be settled in good time to purchase suitable goods for same. Mine was thrown so late that I had very little choice of toys; as I had to take the fag-end of everybody's leavings. The farm instructor will bear me out that this was so, as he was at the store when I purchased them.

I think I have now shewn enough of my grievances to show you the reason for my resignation; grievances which I thought it more straightforward to tell you than to say nothing.

In closing, I would like to suggest, first in the interests of the Indian Department for the better maintenance of their affairs, and in the interests of the Bighead Indians, that, when we give up office here, a farm instructor should be stationed.

Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed a letter from Bishop Macdonald of Prince Albert who writes in reference to Fort Le Couteau Indian School.

The Bishop wrote me last week asking if we could go to the fort and I have written to the Secretary of Indian Affairs, as I was not aware that the Educational section came under separate supervision.

I surmise that the Secretary has placed the matter in your hands and I wish to say that if the Department could give me an idea of the terms that may secure an agreement I could make any arrangements accordingly.

I have just finished with a summer school near here and was about to join my brother on the homestead but would be prepared to wait until June 15th, 1912, should the Department be making a change with the new year.

I would like to give you briefly details of my past experience. I have spent five years teaching in...
England, British Canada, for six months under the Indian Department at Fairford in 1905-6. The salary I had to throw up on account of the small salary & high cost of living $25 a month without any accommodation. I was saving to get married at the time, but the cost of reaching the place during these last few months pocket.

Lately I have been turning my attention to the farm for I find there is nothing to look forward to in the teaching profession that is under the present Provincial administration. Teaching is a mere stepping stone to other professions.

At the same time I am very fond of children and the schoolroom. I keep a firm hold on the pupils and always get on well with them and I am able to give up the school especially as I find the heavy work of the farm beyond my strength. From my experience at Fairford together with the salary recommendation the dept. now offer I feel certain the position would be permanent, all things being satisfactory, & I believe I could do good work.

Of course I have no details of what work is required and ordinary school work would not be altogether satisfactory in an Indian School. I am however an enthusiast of practical work, and would endeavour to earn the boys cultivating plots of vegetables in...
School house garden, if same should be fenced, also, if permitted, instruct them in carpentry during the winter season.

Of course I understand that the department could not undertake any expenditure in this way.

My wife also is well fitted with regards washing, keeping the house, &c., &c.

Should you consider my application satisfactory, I would wish to remain. I parallel for some time, my brothers are working the farm and would be some distance away.

I trust you will give me your kindest consideration, and while of course I would like to go to the post as soon as possible, would be happy to wait the department's pleasure, if they could give me some idea of the duties that I would be required.

Yours truly,

P.H. Guttenman.

The enclosed letter from Indian Agent W. J. Borthwick, dated November 13th, was received by me upon Saturday Nov 18th. After fully considering its contents, I decided that it was undesirable to move Mr. Godfrey and our family into such limited accommodation as the old building at Steurgeon Lake Day School, but that it would be the right thing to go to Steurgeon Lake myself to cater for the men employed there and to help in the completion of the building.

On Nov 22nd, Farmer J. McCloy of Fort la Corne drove out with me to Kinistino to enable me to board the train for Prince Albert leaving Kinistino Nov 23rd.

This train was over five hours late owing to a severe snowstorm on the 22nd, and it was after four P.M. when I reached Prince Albert, too late to make the trip of 25 miles from P.A. to Steurgeon Lake that day, considering the heavy fall of snow.

Sir,

Your letter of Dec 20th came to hand Dec 30th.

The contents thereof were a great surprise to me because I had received a letter from Mr Inspector Chisholm informing me that I had done well in returning to Fort la Corne, also that the new building at Sturgeon Lake would not be ready until spring.

On receiving your letter, it seemed to me the best plan would be to have an interview with Mr Chisholm or some other official who would be in a position to report the true state of affairs to the Dept.

To do this, on Jan 2nd I hired an Indian to drive into Kinistino with me, where I telegraphed to Mr Chisholm to ascertain if he was at home at Prince Albert.

While awaiting an answer (which was four hours in coming) I received information that Mr Gentleman was in Kinistino and was about to engage a livery team to drive out to South la Corne school to take charge.
After a mutual introduction and exchange of letters Mr. Gentleman decided to accompany me to Prince Albert if the expected reply was favorable. At last the message came "Will be out of town tomorrow and rest of week home on Monday." Message received Jan 2nd time 16:30 O'clock. This meant that we must reach Prince Albert before 7 O'clock on the 3rd.

The next passenger train did not leave Kinistino until about 8 O'clock on the 3rd. A livery team for a drive of forty miles in the night with the temp -35 below zero was out of the question. The only way was to wait around in the cold, in the hope of getting through to Prince Albert on a freight train due about 2 AM at Kinistino. This freight train reached Kinistino at 5 AM and our illegal ride in the caboose cost us $2 each (minus a receipt) but we reached Prince Albert just in time to meet Mr. Chisholm.

Indian Agent Mr. Borthwick was also in Prince Albert so that we were able to hold a consultation. The earliest date Mr. Borthwick could give as to when the new building at Sturgeon Lake will be ready is Feb 1st.

I took no receipts of expenses on this journey.
as I was not under orders, and I walked home from Kinistino; (three hours hard walking) as I could not afford a livery team being already 7 dollars out of pocket, plus two days without pay.

It is not my duty to censure Officials but I trust the Dept will understand that I am not in a position to spend time and money running round the country simply because some one (who is being paid) has been misinforming the Dept as to the real state of affairs at Sturgeon Lake.

I remain

Yours obediently

W. Godfrey

Sir,

I beg to submit a short account of the work done at this school during the past three months.

I have devoted the time mainly to Arithmetic and Reading, the elder boys now being able to work the first four rules using Kirklands Arithmetic as far as exercise 29. The girls having mastered addition and subtraction; as well as the Multiplication and addition tables, I have used every possible way to get them to count quickly and correctly, and with the exception of the two youngest, they have made progress.

I have spent considerable time in teaching the children common everyday words, I have used large coloured posters, taking up the entire side of one wall, and have made excellent progress, one very successful one being a huge poster by Hassel of three children riding on donkeys, and they have all been able to learn to spell, and write over a hundred words from this poster, I have also given them dictation, and they can compose their own answers to questions set about the posters.

I have also given them a good deal of nature study and I find this appeals to them, and they are quick to learn any word connected with an animal.

I have used the "First Victorian Reader" with the boys, and the Ontario Primer with the younger children, but have paid more attention to getting them to read sentences from the board that they can more easily understand, for I find they are inclined to read from the book in a very dull dismal voice which seems to be time wasted. I notice however they are beginning to read from their readers of their own accord, especially the animal stories.

I have used daily the textbook on Calisthenics which they enjoy, the also can sing very well, better than white schools that I have had experience with.

I have also given the boys some lessons in woodwork, and taught them to use the tools, and had we been staying I would have had them at work in the garden.

I have read, and explained parts of Scripture to them, and they can say the LORD'S PRAYER and Grace before the midday meal.

The number on the register is twelve, and the average attendance eight but this is including three girls who are now past school age, and since the snow went away the attendance is very poor.

Yours truly,

Sir,

I have the honour to bring to your notice, that I understand that Mr Gentleman has received intimation of the Department's intention of transferring him to one of the schools at the James Smith's reserve, and while visiting that reserve to count the cattle last week, Farmer McCloy & I went into the matter of the number of children of school age able to attend there. As it is the South school that is vacant I surmise it may be this school that the Department are thinking of opening. The farmer & I enquired of the people at the south end, & I find that there are 15 children who could attend, there being a possible average attendance of 12 at the south end. I also understand that the Indians at that end are anxious to have this school opened again and on account of the good farming land at that end, one or two families who are wishing to go more into their farming operations are moving from the north end, for this purpose, & to be near the school as they have the idea that they could persuade the Department to open the school if there are enough children to attend.

On account of the good land, I think this will be the largest school on that reserve in a few years time. There are several young married families with children growing up in this neighbourhood, most of the ex-pupils that the Department have assisted to make a start having chosen this location.

Having found this out, and having to pass the school buildings on my way, I investigated the state of the buildings. I find the School-house in good repair, but the teachers residence is a difficulty. This is a small log structure belonging to the English Church. It is small about 30' x 30', with a small kitchen. There is
cellar, or cupboards or any place for storage of provisions that would be required to be kept on hand for the children's mid-day meal. There are one or two windows out, & it would not seem to me from the few minutes that were necessary to look it over as being a suitable place to use for the purposes that it has been used for. Also being owned by the Church, I do not know who can be held responsible for its repairs.

Naturally Mr & Mrs Gentleman knowing the place do not take kindly to giving up their present house in exchange for one of this nature, but at the same time as it seems that a successful school could be carried on, & seems to be required the matter will need some attention. I do not like asking anyone to take up the work at this point & having to use the present accommodation, & if the transfer is to be made it would be well if the Department could give this matter very careful attention, & I think that before the school is opened some proper accommodation should be made, or in sending anyone to the present house, it should be on the understanding that an arrangement will be arrived at with the Church authorities to enlarge & fix the present house, or that the Department will provide a small house, at no distant date. Certainly something would have to be done before the present house could be used in the winter, & it would be advisable to consider this early in the year before having & harvest seasons during which time it is so difficult to obtain satisfactory labour.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have been quite unable until now to write the suggested letters to you as to some of the matters we discussed. I beg now to lay the following requests and comments before you. I shall repeat some points discussed and dropped as impossible at present, because I want to have them on your files, as a reminder of what is desired and what I fully believe is due to your Indian work:

1. I beg to apply for a substantial grant for the enlargement and improvement of the Lac la Ronge School building. The school is always full. We could obtain many more pupils from Stanley, Pelican Narrows, Montreal Lake, etc., were we enabled to provide accommodation. The school is well managed and efficient, at no extra cost to the I.D., though at the expense of the Church. The inclination of the I.D. is to dispense gradually with Day Schools in favour of Boarding Schools. If the I.D. cannot find the necessary funds, I would ask that it seriously endeavours to obtain them from the rather large Reserve funds of these Lac la Ronge Indians, now in the hand of the I.D. and lying idle.

2. I would make the same suggestion as to funds in the case of necessary improvements to school and teacher's residence at Big Head's Reserve, South la Corne. The I.D. desires me to obtain a teacher for this Reserve. I can not do so until a proper residence is furnished. You yourself know how unfit for habitation is the old house, and you have said that it is not right for me to send a man to such a house. Meanwhile, there is a fine house and a good school at James Smith's Reserve, Fort a la Corne, unused for some time now, as the I.D. closed the school. It seems to me that there are three alternatives: (1) To build a new house for the teacher and repair the school, or, (2) to move the Fort a la Corne school and house to Big Head's, or, (3) to move it to some central place to serve both reserves, and then to renew the old plan of collecting the children daily by a carrier's route. The funds to be found as I have suggested above. If you re-build, a well needs to be dug also.

3. I would again earnestly press for enlargement of the Onion Lake School. It is doing fine work, see Agent Sibbald's reports, and could get 20 more children, if allowed. This would relieve to some extent the reproach of there being no school for Thunderchild's and Sweet Grass Reserves, and would also enable us to carry on the school more economically. The funds could, if necessary, be provided here also from the Band's funds in the hands of the I.D. Pardon me, if I again repeat, that the I.D. in failing to furnish the Indians with proper educational facilities is laying itself open to grave reproach.
