4. Please let the I.D. remember that I have been for 3 or 4 years begging for a Day School for Thunderchild's Reserve, and a school or a Board-Matron for Sweet Grass. These ought to be supplied or the children otherwise provided for.

5. There is great and pressing need for another Boarding School to accommodate the following Reserves: Mistawasis (Snake Plain), Sandy Lake, Sturgeon Lake and New Reserve, John Smith's, James Smith's, Big Head's, and perhaps Montreal Lake, - 7 or 8 Reserves. I understand that many of those interested in the Indians believe in increasing the number of Boarding Schools and decreasing that of Day Schools.

6. I have just had a most interesting conference with the Sioux (Dakota) Indians north of Prince Albert, the two bands, Tomma Ainyamke's and Anpetu-wasioua's, now united in one, viz., the Round Plain. I believe they are not Treaty Indians, and are mainly heathen. They beg most earnestly for a school, and I have promised to do what I can towards getting it. There are some 14 or 15 children of school age, and other younger ones coming on. They say that the farmers round would send children to this school. So perhaps I could get a grant also from the Saskatchewan Provincial Government, and with that and the I.D. grant a school could be maintained. They have a school building and teacher's house which could be made fit for use without great expense. What can you do for them?

7. As to Mr. Graham's suggestion for John Smith's Reserve, to remove the Lows and appoint a married Farm Instructor and a woman teacher, I am writing to him that I greatly deprecate it, at least for the present. It would not be fair to the Lows who have only lately removed there, and are doing good work. I have no other Reserve with a decent house for the teacher. A woman teacher would not do so well there, these children require a man. Mrs. Low can look after mid-day meals, and if necessary the Dispensing, far better than could a Farm Instructor and wife. There is a good excuse for the Farm Instructor but not near the school. I should strongly suspect any such move as long as Mr. Schmidt remains Indian Agent. It would be contrary to the expressed intention of the I.D. to stop the old scandals of corrupt Indian Agents and Farmers and to give us a better class. I hope you will not sanction it.

While speaking of Mr. Graham, I wish to express my opinion that his methods and acts, while they may (?) be for the benefit of Indian Reserves in the South of this Province, have so far been detrimental to, or careless of, those in the North. We have not had a School Inspector since he carried off Mr. Crombie.

8. I repeat, that you may have it on file, that I find it quite impossible with the present H.C.L. and high wages to procure proper teachers at $600 or even $700. They can get $1,000 or $1,200 for teaching British, Canadian, or Foreign day-schools.

May I ask you to have me supplied in writing with either a list of the salaries attached to each Saskatchewan Day School, or a general statement of salaries and bonus now given to improved Day Schools. Hoping you will not be angry at the length of my letter and my requests and looking for a reply,

I remain,

Dear Mr. Graham,

A short time ago I had the pleasure of a visit from His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan, when we discussed generally educational matters affecting his diocese. I asked him to place his requests and recommendations in writing and he has done so. I wish now to take up with you the question of the school on the south Fort a la Corne reserve. As you know there is no proper accommodation there for a teacher. The Bishop makes three alternative proposals - (1) To build a new house for the teacher and repair the school, (2) to move the Fort a la Corne school and house to Big Head's, (3) to move it to some central place to serve both reserves, and then to renew the old plan of collecting the children daily by a carrier's route.

I am told that it is not practicable to move the school building from the north reserve; we had the matter looked carefully into on a previous occasion. I am not in favour of transporting the children to school; our experience in this respect has been far from satisfactory. It seems to me, therefore, that in order to provide for the education of these children, pending the carrying out of a more extensive system of boarding schools which of necessity cannot be consummated for some time, the only course is to provide a house for the teacher in the most economical way possible. I shall be glad to have your views on the subject.

Yours very truly,

Gentlemen:

I have the honour to request that you give the following letter your consideration.

The School of which I am privileged to be Teacher of (Fort a la Corne North Day School) has a roll of pupils amounting to thirty with an average attendance of twenty-two, and if the complete school roll was in attendance there would not be sufficient room in the aforementioned school to hold them, as at the present time of writing I have only one empty desk at my disposal.

I have been considering matters relative to the educational advantages of the children on the James Smith Reserve and I am given to understand that the South End is not open and in all probability will not be opened until spring of 1921, and I am further led to understand that the school roll on the South End School would amount to twenty. Drawing up these inferences I have come to the following conclusion and trust that you will take my suggestions in the way in which they are sent to you.

If the Department deem it advisable I fail to see any obstacle in the way of having the South End School transferred to the North End School, in other words that would make a necessary addition to the North End School which will be necessary anyway if the entire roll of the children at the North End are present at school, all the children from both schools could be under my tuition and thus save the Department a needless expense. I am further led to understand that there will be an erection of another building at the South End School, I have personally looked around the said school and if I may say so I am of the opinion that a new school is not necessary, and all that it requires is a little overhauling which could be done at a very little expense.

Needless to say this idea of mine comes under the Consolidated School System. This system has proved a great success amongst the public schools and I believe that the same success would be realized amongst the Indian people here. It is my opinion that an Indian could be hired to drive a team for the children from the South End School at a salary of forty or fifty dollars ($40.00 or $50.00) a month and there are Indians on this Reserve who have the horses which would suit just for that purpose.

I trust that you will realize that I am only just bringing this idea to you from an educational and financial standpoint. I am very interested in the Indian Work and since I have been here a number of the young men have asked me as to whether I would give them school at night so as they could improve their English language and needless to say I willingly agreed to do so and am glad to be able to report that my efforts...
We up to the present time been very encouraging and it is because I want every child on this Reserve to have the advantage of an education that I am taking upon myself the liberty of making the suggestion to you.

Apart from this fact may I further state that this would bring the Reserve into a healthier surrounding, because the children from the South End could have all the medical treatment which they required and I would also be more in touch with the physical condition of their parents. I am using every effort which lays at my disposal to place these Indians on more a healthier footing than what they have been accustomed to live in, and I am glad to be able to report that the physical condition of these people are improving but that it will require all the efforts which we on this Reserve can utilize to bring such a thing to pass, for the Indians has apparently no idea whatever as to what they should do to keep morally and mentally clean especially in times of sickness.

Apologizing for any liberty which I have taken in making this suggestion to you,

I have the honour to be,

Sirs,

your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No.109-6-1 dated March 31st last, stating that Rev.R.McLennan of Fort a la Corne, Sask., had written the Department requesting that the Fort a la Corne South School, on James Smith's reserve, be re-opened, and asking me to report on the conditions at this point.

In reply I beg to state that there are 59 children at this end of the reserve, whose names, ages, and distance they live from the school site I am giving on the attached list.

With the exception of the stable, which is a frame building erected about six years ago, there are no suitable buildings at this school. A new school room and teachers residence will have to be erected. The present school room, which is a very old log building, lathed and plastered, is badly rotted and cannot be repaired properly; the plaster outside is falling off through age and wear, the bottom logs are rotten and the building is sagging.

The old log building which was used as a teachers residence is not habitable; these buildings should be torn down and the new buildings erected on the same site.

I would recommend that a teachers house and school room, similar to those at the Fort a la Corne North School be built, and that a married couple, who have had western experience, be engaged, he to teach, and she to take up the duties of Field Matron for the South End of the reserve. This would be the same arrangement as was in force when this school was open in the past.

I would not recommend the appointment of a single teacher.

A new well is required at this school as the old well is caved in and cannot be repaired.

The South School is distant, approximately, ten miles from the North School.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent

You will remember that it is your intention to discuss with Mr. Inspector Murison the advisability of moving the Fort a la Corne North day school ten miles to the south of the reserve, where there are a large number of our wards of school age.

From reports on file, it appears that there are 26 children of school age living within two miles of the site of the old Fort a la Corne South school. The local Church of England missionary and His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan have on several occasions urged the re-opening of the Fort a la Corne South Indian day school. There are no suitable buildings available, with the exception of the stable; so the provision of a classroom and a teacher's residence would have to be made. In addition, a well is required.

Sometime ago the question of moving the Fort a la Corne North school buildings to the south of the reserve was discussed. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo No. 109-9-1, with reference to the education of Indian children on the James Smith Reserve.

At one time I was of the opinion that the Fort a la Corne North School could be moved to a more central part and provide an educational centre for all the children on the reserve. This I find, however, is not feasible, and my recommendation is that the present Fort a la Corne North School, which has now an enrollment of 18 children, with an average attendance of 12, and the possibility of having this enrollment increased by 8 within the next year, should not be interfered with, especially in view of the fact that the central portion of the reserve is very sparsely settled.

With regard to the re-establishment of a school on the South end of the reserve, I think that a school should be built in the neighbourhood of where the old building is. There are no doubt sufficient children in this area to keep a school open the year round. For, as you say, there are 26 children of school age living within two miles of where this school would be, with a possibility of this number increasing. I would, therefore, recommend that the present North School remain where it is, and that a new school be built at the South end.

Dear Sir:

I wish to give notice that the South Day School James Smith Res will be closed on Wednesday Oct 31st & part of Thurs Nov 1st - the reason being that the little girl I have working for me has a chronic eye infection - & it is necessary to see an eye Dr at once.

I intend taking her to Dr Bede at Prince Albert. The girl is not old enough to go alone & her parents are too far North from here. As it would be too dark to drive from Kinistino on Wednesday night I will be back as early as possible on Thurs morning.

Trusting this will meet with your approval.

Signed, Mrs. E.M. Siddons.

Sir:

I have the honour to ask for authority to have the well at the Fort a la Carne South Day School cleaned at an approximate cost of $40.00.

The well which is sixty-one feet deep by thirty-seven inches in diameter was bored in 1925, and has not been cleaned out since, there being no well boring machine in the district which could be hired to do the work.

Mr. Norman Thompson, of Kinistine has informed us that he will bring his machine into the district this summer, before harvest, and offers to clean the well on the following terms:

"He is prepared to clean the well for $25.00 plus an additional $2.00, per day to cover board for two men and team of horses.

This will include the taking out of the upper ten feet of curbing, and replacing it with new. The Department to provide the new curbing.

He guarantees to make a good job, providing the curbing in the bottom of the well does not cave in when he bales the water out. In the event of this happening he expects to be paid the same as though the job were completed."

I recommend that this offer be accepted, as when this machine leaves the district it may be several years before it returns, and it is most important that after ten years use of the well it should be properly cleaned.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith, a requisition for supplies for the Fort a-la-Corne, South Indian Day School.

I beg to report that when visiting this Reserve with Mr. E.S. Jones, Farming Instructor, last November, we called at this school and in questioning Mr. Jones as to the water supply in the well at the school, I was informed that it could not be used by the children, but was alright for livestock.

At that time Mrs Siddons and her husband drew my attention to the fact that the rope being used in this well was too short. This I also referred to Mr. Jones and was given to understand that this well was being used principally by Mr. and Mrs Siddons to water their driving horse, and I feel sure that the rope listed on the attached requisition is for this purpose.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith requisition for supplies for the Fort la Corne South Indian Day School.

Mrs E.M.Siddons advises me that there is no wheel barrow at this school and one is required to haul away the rubbish which collects around the school yard. In this I agree.

She also advises that the rope which was not allowed in view of the report in my letter to the Department, dated January 15th, last under file 1976-15-100 S, is required on account of the supply of water being hauled for the use of the school is in adequate for the use of the school and the teachers residence. Also that the rope in use at present is so short that it is dangerous to use.

Mail service to this point is at present very uncertain owing to the condition of the roads. It is also liable to be a matter of weeks before I will have occasion to visit this point and be able to find out if all the items requisitioned for are required. I would therefore request authority to purchase the items listed if, and when the necessity of doing so arises.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Dear Sir,

I beg to advise that the well used for supplying water for the Fort à la Corne South Indian Day School and Teacher's Residence has gone dry and it is necessary to have a new well dug.

It is estimated that a sufficient supply of water can be procured at a depth of from 16 to 20 feet. The cost of Indian labour to dig the well and crib would be one dollar per foot for a four foot square hole. There is sufficient lumber on hand for the cribbing but approximately 25 lbs. of 4" spikes will be required at a cost of $2.00.

I beg to request authority to have this work done at a total cost of approximately $22.00.

Yours very truly,

S. H. Simpson

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to report that a section of the cement foundation of the Teacher's residence at the Fort a la Corne South Day School has cracked near the top and broken away from the main part. Also that the lean to porch on this building has broken away from the main building.

The break in the cement foundation permits cold air to penetrate into the building during the cold weather and makes it difficult to heat the building. The space between the porch and building also permits cold drafts through the door leading therefrom into the building.

2 - 98 lb. sacks of cement @ $1.35 and Indian labour amounting to approximately $8.00 will be required to make the necessary repairs.

I beg to request authority to expend the sum of $11.00 to have these repairs made.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

In the 1944-45 Estimates, Duck Lake Agency, a request was made for interior decorations of the teachers' residence, at John Smith's Reserve, Moose Woods Sioux Reserve, James Smith Reserve, and Kinistino Reserve.

I would recommend that these be approved of and granted. Mr. Simpson, the Agency, states that with respect to the interior decorations at the John Smith Day School and floors in the dining room and hall way are badly worn and in the first place there is only a one-ply lumber. There is sufficient experienced Indian labour on the reserve to do the work.

The Agent also request that if funds are available outside repairs be made to the Fort a La Corne North Indian Day School. This building is in bad need of re-painting. I also notice that the South School on the same reserve could do with a re-painting but at the present time it is in better shape than the school north of it.

Duck Lake Sask., Aug. 7th 1945.

J. P. B. Ostrander, Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

Enclosed herewith please find requisition listing materials and labour required for decorating various day schools in Duck Lake Agency, as requested in your letter No. 305-11A dated August 3rd.

As finances may not be available to carry out all of the repairing and decorating asked for in this Agencies 1944-5 estimates the enclosed requisition covers the estimated costs of repairing and decorating that should be done this year, and in order of importance.

1. Moose Woods (Whitecap) Sioux day school.

The class room is in poor condition and should be repaired and decorated as soon as possible. Decorating materials were secured last year from 1943-4 estimates and due to the Plaster on walls and ceilings being badly cracked and falling off it was decided to postpone decorating until the plaster was removed and replaced by wall board. The Sum of $137.88 is required to cover the costs of materials and labour. Decorating materials are on hand and the work will be completed at the time of removal of the old plaster and replacing with Wallboard.

2. James Smith South day school & Tsamhhrs residence.

The building and grounds are very dirty and untidy and the buildings and grounds should be cleaned up properly before the Teacher assumes her duties on September 2nd next as a change in the teaching staff is being made at this school this coming term the premises should be in fair condition in order to impress on the incoming teacher the importance of keeping the buildings and grounds in proper condition. As this school is situated approximately 7 miles distant from the Department Farm buildings on James Smith Reserve proper fire guard protection should be provided. In the event of a bush or grass fire originating on the reserve during the fall and early spring months I am afraid that the buildings would become a total loss.

With reference to the remainder of the day school estimates outlined in my letter No. 4950-2I dated July 30th the work can be completed as and when finances are available and if necessary can be completed next season.

Ottawa, 19 December 1946.

Mr. N.J. McLeod, Indian Agent,
DUCK LAKE, Sask.

When reporting on his inspection of the Fort a la Corne South School on Nov. 15, the Public School Inspector writes as follows:

"On the morning of my visit the room was cold and very uncomfortable. The furnace is burnt out and seemed to give more smoke than heat. Some window panes are out and this made the situation all the worse. A new furnace should be installed and steps built to the "cellar" to replace the ladder-box combination that serves as a means of descending. At present the whole thing is dangerous, to say the least.

"The plaster needs patching and the whole building needs painting thoroughly, and completely. The floor has been painted recently, and is in fair condition, except the cellar doorway. The blackboards are poor and should be re-surfaced with slating. There are insufficient desks to seat the pupils; these should have been requisitioned long ago. Children can hardly be expected to attend school when they have nowhere to sit."

Please let me hear from you in regard to the above. In connection with the desks, I presume that the 6 new desks had not reached the school at the time of the Inspector's visit.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Reference is made to your letter dated December 19th, your file No. 109-9-8 (W.T.I.) regarding report of the Public School Inspector in connection with the condition of the South Day School on James Smith Reserve No. 100, Fort la Corne, Sask.

The remarks of the Inspector are noted and while I agree with his recommendations in part, arrangements are being made to move the class room and teacher's residence to a more suitable location, where good water supplies are available. Provisions for this work are included in Duck Lake Agency Estimates 1947-48.

In regard to the condition of the furnace, in view of the alterations planned for 1947, it was not deemed advisable to install a new furnace and temporary repairs were made which did not prove satisfactory and we have discontinued the use of the present furnace and installed a large cast iron heater in the class room, which provides ample heating arrangements.

With reference to school class desks, these were ordered in 1946 estimates and were delivered recently and in addition, the Principal of Duck Lake Indian Residential School handed over 11 good used desk seats, these were all installed in the south day school class room.

Some difficulty was experienced in securing window glass due to short supply. However all broken window glass have now been repaired and I believe the class room is in as good a condition as possible under existing conditions and with a view to alterations planned for the coming year.

In regard to improvements planned for the 1947 year. Extensive alterations and repairs are required, including installation of a new furnace and removal of the buildings a distance of approximately 1½ to 2 miles, where suitable water supplies can readily be made available.

It is anticipated this method will overcome the present difficulties in regard to the condition of this particular building set up and when completed should prove satisfactory and be the means of securing the services of a more competent teacher than we now have at the south school.

N.J. McLeod
Indian Agent.

Reference is made to 1947-48 Estimates, Schools, Repairs, Buildings and Works.

Allowance has been made in the above estimates for the moving of the James Smith's South Indian Day School from its present location to a new location about 2 miles distance.

The last Farmer in charge, left without giving any reason, but I believe it was Mr. Godfrey's interference. The present Farmer, McCloy, has sent in his resignation to take effect on March 1st., giving as his reason that there is not room for himself and Mr. Godfrey on the reserve. Now Mr. McCloy is a most capable man, thoroughly competent in every way, and the Agency cannot afford to lose such men from any such reason.

It may be said that Mr. Godfrey would cause the same trouble on the John Smith's Reserve. I do not think so; the Indians are a different class, while as to the Farmer, it would be no great loss if he found there was not room enough on the reserve for himself and Mr. Godfrey. The annoyance caused by Mr. Godfrey is not new, having been going on for the past five years but in view of the very valuable services of Mrs. Godfrey, I have not before commented on it. Dear Sir:

re. Your letter of Dec. 16. and telegram of Dec. 20, 1910. Reference 117084/1.

Your letter to me (just received) re. Rev. R. Macdougall and John Smith's Reserve, and Mr. MacArthur's telegram to him, are inexplicable to me without knowing the previous correspondence to which you refer and I cannot possibly let the matter rest as it is. I am writing to Agent MacArthur, and also to Mrs. Godfrey telling her not to consider the offer to her till she hears from me that I consent. I am obliged to act in this manner, for your action, or Mr. MacArthur's has created a most difficult position. The I.D. has hitherto always consulted me in appointments and changes most courteously and I have always done the same by them. It is not to be accepted that the Agent shall step in between us and upset all arrangements. The appointment of Mr. MacDougall has been made for over a year, the delay until the last three months came from the I.D., not from us, there was never a hint given that you were not satisfied with his views and aims, or thought of reconsidering the appointment. Then, when he has resigned his parish and broken up his home, comes a wire from MacArthur, not from you, saying, "You can stay at Radisson; other arrangements made for John Smith's." You surely can see, Sir, that not only is this change an unfair one, but the wording of the telegram is very nearly insolent. What has MacArthur to do with Radisson? I can make arrangements for my parishes without the advice of an Indian Agent.

Let me recall the circumstances:-

1. The I.D. notified us that John Smith's was to have an "improved day school"
"improved day school" of the most perfect kind. This was early in 1909. The I.D. suggested, or else welcomed our suggestion, that Mr. and Mrs. MacDougall should have the appointment.

Then followed a disheartening delay. My Indian teacher left, and I had difficulty in securing him again. Mr. MacDougall was kept in anxiety; he did not know what to tell his parishioners; the rumour got out that he was leaving them. If Mr. MacDougall betrayed a little irritation in his letters (as you seem to say, if I understand) it was natural. Archdeacon MacKay and myself wrote to the I.D. at times, only to be assured that Mr. MacDougall was desired and all would be ready as soon as possible. Mr. MacDougall offered to go at once and superintend the building, this was declined. I finally wrote that I must have the appointment confirmed or I must withdraw MacDougall's name. The appointment was confirmed. After some twelve or eighteen months we were told all would be ready in September 1910. Unfortunately Mrs MacDougall was in England, very ill (in hospital), and Mr. MacDougall overworked and he could not face the change singlehanded. So permission was obtained for some delay. Finally it was settled that he should go just before Christmas, but Inspector Chisholm kindly advised Christmas at Radisson, and that the work should begin on January 3rd.; and he said he would so advise MacArthur and the I.D. There had never been a hint given that the I.D. was not satisfied. Then followed a short correspondence between MacDougall and MacArthur faults, I daresay on both sides; MacDougall very foolishly said he would rather not accept if there was going to be friction over small matters (or some such expression). But he resigned his Church, broke up his home, sold his horse and made all preparations to go to John Smith's. Then came MacArthur's wire conveying your decision, too hastily made, but conveying it in an unnecessarily rude manner. I think the I.D. should have at least consulted with myself or Arch-Deacon MacKay after all the correspond-

Dear Sir,- There seems to be a misunderstanding over our correspondence. I have not a copy of my last letter here, and consequently cannot refer to it as intelligently as I would wish, but permit me to state: That I really had no intention of offending anyone, particularly you.

That I had not thought of resigning and would not have done so under any circumstances as I had given up everything here to accept the position at John Smith's.

Regarding the word "friction" what I meant was that if the Department and myself could not work amicably I would resign, and I think you would honor me for it, but I would of course give no cause for complaint nor do I anticipate friction.

And I may add, particularly with you, as I know that you are interested in the education of the Indian and would go far to help one who has the same interest as yourself.

Re- oil and wood. I never made it an issue- I spoke to Mr. Chisholm, and do not know whether he recommended it or not. He, I think, referred it to you. Re- anything I said respecting salary. I had accepted all the Dept's terms, and I wished to convey the idea that my motives were not entirely mercenary- And they were not- . I love the Indian work and in consequence, I threw up my position here and broke up my home to go to John Smith's.

I trust that you will do what you can to rectify matters. If not, you a great injury will be done one whom I know you would never have trouble or friction with.

Yours Sincerely,

(Sgd.) R.F. Macdougall.

P.S.- If you wish to see me, wire and I can come & explain more fully.

Referring to departmental letter of the 19th ult., relative to the application of Rev. R. F. McDougall, of John Smith's reserve, for increased remuneration for his duties, I have the honour to report as follows:

Mr. McDougall continues to discharge his duties as teacher on the whole with marked success. It is true his methods in some subjects could be improved, and he devotes a large share of attention to drills and other physical exercises intended for display in the presence of visitors; but he has also kept in view the educational value of these exercises and the advantage to be gained from their use in drawing out timid and self-conscious Indian children and leading them to forget themselves. By these and similar means, too, the daily routine of the school is so varied as to become thoroughly enjoyable to the pupils; and as a consequence they come to school cheerfully and regularly, and with remarkable punctuality at the hour for opening, 9 o'clock.

A new school building was not by any means indispensable here, as the old one is fairly comfortable, in good repair, was provided with a new and well-constructed porch within the past few months, and affords something above the minimum floor-space and air-space. It is, of course, heated by a large box stove; and in winter, when this is in use to its full capacity it is clear that the work cannot be conducted with the same convenience and advantage that will be

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
afforded in the new and up-to-date building that is now in course of construction; and with such guarantee as the Department has in this instance of the improved facilities being utilized to full advantage the expenditure cannot be deemed unwarranted.

As for the work of the reserve, it is necessarily directed by the teacher mainly from home, as he has but a limited time after 4 p.m. and on Saturdays to go abroad, which is especially true during the short days of Fall and Winter. I found Mr. McDougall, however, fairly well informed regarding the work of the Indians and the state of affairs generally throughout the reserve; and his counsel to the Indians in connection with their industries has certainly been more effective thus far than that of any farmer on this reserve for many years past. In the matter of grain growing there is this season a considerable increase in acreage; and during the summer more plowing has been done than in any other season for some years. Mr. McDougall does not attempt to direct the farming and live stock industries in detail; but he keeps a general supervision, and for the most part the Indians listen to his advice and encouragement and follow it cheerfully.

In his capacity as farmer, teacher and missionary Mr. McDougall has exercised a noticeable influence over the younger and middle-aged Indians in regard to temperance, which it is to be hoped may be lasting.

I may mention, though not directly connected with the present question, that as matron and nurse Mrs. McDougall is constant in her attention to duty, and a great help to Mr. McDougall in his management of the school and the reserve. Both Mr. and Mrs. McDougall are now well tried in Indian work, and there is little room to fear any decrease in their efficiency; and I accordingly consider the conditions would justify some allowance to Mr. McDougall for his duties in the supervision of the reserve.
I inspected the reserve and school in the beginning of September; but owing to the fact that my time has been completely occupied with fresh work arising from day to day which had to be attended to at once I have not as yet been able to prepare a report on my inspection.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

I have to inform the Department that according to the recent instructions, I left the Duck Lake Agency on the 27th ultimo and reached John Smith's two days later. Mr Schmidt gave me the use of two teams, and hired an ox team for the transfer.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No. 117084/1 of the 9th inst., respecting the opening of the school here on August 11, and in reply I must state that I regret that the Department should have gathered from my report that the classroom work is dependent on the mid-day meal, as this is not so.

At the same time, in reporting the matter I may not have made the circumstances quite clear, and I beg to submit a further note on the matter. As the Department are aware, at the beginning of July also on the first of August I issued a much reduced ration to the widows and destitute which in itself caused much discussion on the reserve, at the same time I refused entirely to ration the working Indians that were putting up hay which was the cause of more difficulty and I had quite a hard job to convince these people that they must not expect the Department to provide for them, so much in this way.

Now, the children's dinner was not expected to be reduced, and it did not seem to me to be wise to cause further dissatisfaction among the people by not providing the usual meal, and as I could not do this I thought the matter best overcome by allowing them another weeks holiday, as the only provisions on hand was flour. Now we could not have made a satisfactory meal out of flour alone, and in taking the course I did, I did not lay myself open to more disputes on reduced rations. The children would have noticed the better meal the following week which would have given the impression that a point had been gained, and this was not necessary.

I would add that Mr Macdougall would have purchased fresh beef in Prince Albert under similar conditions, but I had no
authority to do such, and if I had done so, the Duck Lake office would have returned the account to me asking why such a thing had been done, and the extra weeks holiday did not appear to me to be of sufficient importance to give cause for this. It was not as if I did not put in an appearance at the reserve until that date, our time was more or less occupied all June and July here, and as Mr Macdougall did not leave this house until the latter part of July we were in somewhat of a muddled position, still on Aug. 1st.

I would also like to add, if I may be permitted, that I had several talks with Mr Macdougall on this subject, the non arrival of supplies. He considered that the school work was quite important to warrant him purchasing on his own account without authority. The subject interested me as on several occasions while at the Duck Lake office it fell to me to write a reasonable letter of explanation in an effort to get an account of this kind passed. Mr Macdougall also remarked that if the Agent could not, or would not see that supplies were on hand when required, after having good notice, it was up to the man in charge to go ahead on his own account.

On the other hand, Mr Inspector Graham when here, informed me that if the Government saw fit to appoint a man who was not onto the job, I was not in any way to exceed his authority or instructions no matter what they might be, otherwise if this was not satisfactory to myself, I was quite at liberty to leave the service.

However on matters of this kind, I must assure the Department I will use very careful judgement, giving full consideration to the circumstances at the time, I have no desire to act against Mr Schmidt's wishes in anything, but I think if the Department more fully understood the conditions they would see that sometimes it is not wise to carry out instructions exactly to the letter, when such are given from so great a distance.

Sir,

I beg leave to submit herewith a report on the affairs of this reserve in general, and more particularly in connection with the school, also the work of ex-pupils.

As the Department is aware the reserve is about eighteen miles from the city of Prince Albert on the South Saskatchewan and is splendid farming land. Most of the men who are farming are ex-pupils of the Battleford school, or the recent Emmanuel College in Prince Albert, also the half-breed element being very strong make the people here, in my opinion, somewhat in advance of those of James Smiths or Beardys band, but while they have cultivated a good deal of the white mans ways for their good, they have also learned much in the opposite direction which makes them a difficult people to deal with.

In the school, most of the childrens parents are ex-pupils of the Battleford school, or have had some connection with the Boarding schools and the result is very encouraging. The children come to school clean and tidy, nor do they have the odour of skins & fur that is general among the Indian. I find however that they are not so advanced as I expected, but they readily respond to direct teaching with the blackboard and large pictures. I have a large class of young children between six and eight years of age whom I am successfully teaching to read with the aid of very large beautifully coloured posters; the third and fourth grades also making headway with the aid of the London Daily Mirror, the illustrations therein being much looked for each week.

In Arithmetic I have largely confined myself to Addition, subtraction, multiplication and division for the whole school, but the elder children will advance in this from now on. I find them all backward in Arithmetic.
With regards the attendance, the girls are very regular, but the boys have often been kept at home to assist with the haying. This is a difficult matter to deal with, no doubt the elder boys are a help but I am endeavouring to impress upon the parents that this is not approved of. I would suggest that with a reserve of this kind that some form of Application for admission, also discharge be put in force and let the parents well understand that no assistance in the way of a grant would be given to a pupil of the reserve school unless the attendance is satisfactory, also such grants should be made as soon after the pupil leaves school, as possible. At present the boys casually drop out at about thirteen or fourteen, then hang around doing very little for four or five years, whereas if it was possible to keep them for a proper discharge at sixteen, they could have a year or so at home, and then settle them down a little.

The question of ex-pupils assistance and advancement is a very difficult one, and I would mention two instances of what has been done here this summer. One man George Crain who must be twenty-six or seven this spring received sufficient seed wheat for five or six acres. This was sown, but never fenced, and no thought seems to have been given to this. The man put up a little hay for the loan oxen he has, also has the Department waggon on loan most of the summer, but his whole seasons work does not amount to a row of beans. Certainly his wife has been slowly going blind, I sent the man to Dr Strong with her but he went several times to an Eye Doctor in town paying from $2. to $3. a visit, but afterwards coming to me for rations being quite destitute for the time being, and appealing to Mr Chisholm for cash in town. I might also add that a local harness man approached me for information as regards Georges crop as he had a note of $50.00 against him of some years standing. The Bank of Ottawa, I am told by their accountant advanced Crain an amount on his note, also some years back.
but I was not informed of the amount. The man now says that it will be necessary for him to go out and hunt this winter, and is going to Cumberland. Who is to take care of the loan oxen, it is difficult to say, also there are two bright little children that should be at school, and who will quite likely not survive a hard winter's hunt.

Another case of an ex-pupil's work is Harry Badger. This man put in a small crop, and left it to go to the Pas. One of the old widows hedged it with brush, and rails tied with string. The man returned a month ago. The oxen provided for him were very old and slow, and the excuse was that they were too slow. The Agent sold them at the sale, and bought a fine pair of steers from Robert Bear H.M., raising three, for him, which he now claims he cannot break. This might throw another yoke on our hands to see through the winter, as Badger also finds it necessary to go hunting.

There are six or eight young men around between the age of sixteen and twenty whom applications for grants will come from within the next few years, whom, if the Department approves, I would like to help as follows. If a couple of $50.00 grants are to be made next spring, could I get these young men to attend a night school twice a week during the winter, and let them understand that the grants would be made to the man making the best showing. I would give them some careful talking, and advance their Arithmetic etc., and talk plans for the summer work. Perhaps the Department might be able to offer a bridle, or tools as a prize outright, I feel sure that there is good material to work on, and that one of the mistakes is that an assistance grant is made without showing the Indian that some interest is taken in the manner he makes use of it, other than getting the repayments made. I fancy I could reach these young men in the way mentioned if allowed, and the grants made next spring in this way.
Respecting the work of the other men, they have had a very fair summer. The grain has ripened good, and the hay has been fairly plentiful on the high land, but this year is the first that the working Indians have not received rations; and they have sold a large amount of same in Prince Albert. It is possible that some of them have not provided sufficient for their cattle for the coming winter, but I have got hem to understand that the Department will not ration able-bodied men. The recent visit of Mr Chisholm was very successful in this matter as the younger men reminded the Chief of the treaty, who informed them that rations were promised for three years which had long since past.

Up till now there has been no case of serious illness among the people. The Doctor has been out two or three times, and my wife has visited most of the houses, and endeavored to impress upon them the importance of keeping things clean and tidy etc., etc.

Sir,— In reply to your letter of 29th ultimo, No. 117084-1, relative to the conveying of the children of John Smith's Reserve to school during the winter, I have the honour to inform you that while at this reserve the other day the matter was taken up and looked into by Mr. Inspector Chisholm, Mr. Gentleman the teacher and myself.

Mr. Gentleman is very anxious that the children be conveyed to school in order to keep up the attendance. However, in discussing the matter it was proven that only three families lived at any great distance from the school, one, Robert Bear H.M., about two miles east, another, Gilbert Bear, about one and a half miles south and the other, Francis Dreaver, about two miles north-west. This means that it would keep a team very busy in the morning getting the children to school by nine o'clock on account of the distance between the houses.

It appears that in the past when the children were conveyed, those of Robert Bear H.M. and Francis Dreaver were not driven; the driver claiming, it is said, that he was not paid sufficient for the work, which was $1.50 a day.

The children attending this school are mostly young, and it is certain that they will be absent in cold weather and progress will be slow.

I regret to say that I have not kept my diary up to date. On receiving instructions from Mr. Chsiholm to the effect that my duties only went as far as attending to the old people etc., I did not know if a diary was required to be sent in or not. It may be of interest to the Department to have a detailed account of today's doings, (November 3rd)

Rose at 6.20 a.m. Lit two fires & finished breakfast by 7.5, when I went to the stable. Milked, watered & fed horse & cows, and in the middle of cleaning stable about 7.35, Chief arrived for rations. Same having arrived late on Saturday night, had to open case of bacon & tea, to ration Chief which took about 20 minutes, also open dry goods to get him a blanket.

At 8.15 I lit the schoolhouse furnace, carried in wood and water for my own use & children's midday meal. At 8.50 Mrs Dreaver arrived for rations which I issued. At 9.10 I went into school with seven children, the rest arriving between that & 9.25. At 10.45 I rationed Mrs Smith & Mink. School 11 till 12. With the children while they had dinner 12 till 12.30. Had my own lunch 12.30 till 12.50 at which time I blew up a football for the boys, and played with them until 1.5. I then hitched up the horse first having to catch him in the field, as it was necessary for my wife to visit two sick people. At 1.15, I went into school. At 1.40 I advised an Indian respecting a hay matter, at 2.5 another Indian respecting the threshing machine. At 2.50 the Agent called in for a couple of minutes & at 2.45, I rationed. Mrs E. Smith. Mrs Batt issuing blankets also.

School from 3 till 4.5, when I had tea. My wife having returned from the north end & we went at 4.20 to the south end, taking Mrs Badgers rations, and visiting another sick person. We reached home at 5.20, when I watered & fed the animals, and finished cleaning out the stable, which
kept me busy until 6.15, talking to an Indian part of the time whom I got rid of about 6.30. At 6.55 I got into my office, checked over three accounts, receipts etc., also wrote five letters on the Departments business, filed some vouchers, & copies, and looked through the matters that had been left by the Inspector requiring attention.

I would be glad if you could let me know if it would be possible for the Department to allow me the sum of $25.00 to secure an organ that is at present in use in the schoolhouse under the following circumstances.

Sir,

I beg to submit herewith a report on the work of the school children attending the Day school here, also the reserve in general during the quarter ending this week. The detailed information respecting the school is also enclosed.

With the exception of the very small children, I consider they have all made advancement in the different branches of study. I have given considerable time to Arithmetic, the elder girls having mastered Long Division & just beginning multiplication etc of weights & measures, while the three eldest girls have got as far as fractions. The boys all of them, are working at Long Division at the present time, while the small children are still at addition.

Reading exercises etc are carried out daily, the elder girls using the fourth reader & Geography books, which I sometimes use to combine a reading & Geography lesson together. The boys are using the second & third readers, while the younger children are reading from the blackboard. The whole school read one or two verses each every morning from the bible.

All the children write well, and every lesson at which the exercise books are used is made a writing lesson.

The girls also have regular Grammar & Composition lessons twice a week, also Geography which is studied with the boys with the aid of the large wall maps. I give the boys composition lesson in connection with spelling on the blackboard. The elder girls have during the quarter learnt how to draw maps, and the boys have studied house and stable plans each one drawing his idea of the best house, and writing down his reasons for same. All the children have received Nature Study lessons, which
I am able to make very attractive. The children look forward to a weekly Nature Study Drawing lesson. Twenty minutes drill with music has been given each day, also some eight or ten songs were learnt during the quarter, the latter mainly on account of the Christmas tree concert.

In connection with the younger children of whom there are eight or ten who are almost unable to do anything I found that this class caused me considerably difficulty while teaching the elder children, insomuch that it was difficult to keep them busy for any length of time. To overcome this I obtained from London at my own expense an entire outfit of Kindergarten materials, of which I have had experience, & instead of setting them lessons while teaching the elder children, I am using the Kindergarten things; with I think a fair amount of success. They have only been in use a short while, & it is something that has never been done here before. This, with the reading from the board with the big posters will be the work of the little ones for some time to come.

The school term was closed by a Christmas tree Concert last Tuesday at which the entire programme was made up of the childrens songs & recitations, some eighteen items in all. A collection taken up during the evening amounted to $9.46, and one or two parents expressed their satisfaction, in Cree & English, of the childrens work. All my lessons are marked, and at my own expense I gave prizes to the six highest; the marks being totalled weekly, and at the end of the year.

In connection with the attendance I find that the average works out at 28, which I consider fair. The decision of the Department not to drive the children to school has something to do with this & I cannot refrain from making one or two comments on this subject. I must say however that this winter has been most exceptionally warm with very little snow, a condition of affairs I believe prevailing throughout the west at present. Had the weather been cold the average attendance would have been very much lower, and it is a great pity, that having provided an excellent
School building etc., that nothing is done to see or enable the children to make a regular attendance. There is excellent material here to work on, & I would call attention to the late Agent Macarthur's report of a year or so ago in which he stated that the John Smiths school hardly justified its existence at that time, and compare it with now. From my experience with other Indian Day schools which I have taught & visited I can say that the Department have something here that is considerably above the average in every way. The children are neat and tidy, and come to school clean, and I believe I am getting as full attendance as is possible. I would point out that the John Smiths people are considerably advanced in their ways being very much like the white settlers off the reserve, and as it is general in the west the boys are often kept at home during the summer months to help with the work, whereas this could be overcome a good deal if they could be driven during the winter. I would also say that there is only one family attending whom might be called hunters, the others all being Farmers, and the children helping with the chores morning and evening, with short days, makes it very difficult for the children to get to school on time. This should receive consideration.

I must also report that during two weeks of December, in order to ascertain the distance & time etc., I drove the children myself in the morning, on which days I picked up every child of school age on the reserve. The experiment was not made without difficulty, I had to use the buggy and of course a single horse, I found that by leaving the house at eight o'clock I could get every child by 9:30 in three journeys, but of course it meant a great deal of extra work for myself. This could however be worked with the school as a starting center.

In concluding the matter of attendance I would remark that at three white schools within ten miles or so, I am informed that the average attendance is $7 & 8 respectively, with an enrollment of 9,11, & 12.
I must say that it is with no small amount of difficulty that I can give the school the attention that it should have. There is a great deal of difference between "putting in time" and actual teaching, & while I endeavour to teach the whole of schoolhours I often find that I get very tired towards the end of the week. It should be considered that the daily "chores" here mean no small amount of work. The morning work of cleaning the horse & stable, watering, feeding & milking, & four fires to light, with wood to carry to each of them and water to get into the house for the children's midday meal etc., means something. There is an hour and a half of this daily before I can get into school, and similar in the evening. Had the winter been a hard one, it would be impossible to do all this alone, and at the same time do justice to the school.

I would point out the granting of authority to the Agent to hire a man here when required is really of little assistance, as there are often times that a man is needed when it would be impossible to obtain permission from Duck Lake, & this throws a lot of work on myself. Also, I am quite alone, while Mr Macdougall had two boys of his own, who did a great deal of stable cleaning etc., also who could take a message to one of the Indians while if I need anyone it is necessary for me to leave school, or go after schoolhours and find someone.

I cannot understand the Department refusing some kind of assistance, I notice from the Bluebook reports that some of the Boarding school staffs seem to be extensive, notably the Sarcee Boarding School that appears to have an enrollment of sixteen, that needs a staff of four.

Here it is impossible to do much reading on one's own account, and unlike various other teachers, Agents & Inspectors, I have nothing in the shape of a cattle ranch as a sideline, $600, or $800, is not an extensive salary when there is no promotion to look forward to, and absolutely no time for study. Of course it has been pointed out that the Department...
are allowing $15.00 per quarter for help in the house, but I would ask what kind of help can one get from an Indian at $5.00 per month. I have to pay Mrs Badger another $15.00 per quarter out of my own salary for doing a considerable amount of the Departments work. The statement made by Mr Chisholm that the fire for the children's midday meal does not need to be started until eleven o'clock is quite a mistake, & if my wife & I finish breakfast later than eight, the whole day is thrown late. Mrs Badger arrives at the house about 8.30, and starts work at once.

It is also necessary for me to see that beef, flour etc is placed in a handy place in the kitchen, and I bring this from the old schoolhouse which is now used as a warehouse myself.

In making this report I would like to request that the reason for the Departments desire for a monthly diary from me, could be sent. It seems as if someone is endeavouring to find as many reports, forms etc, to fill up at the end of the month as is possible to get. I have no less than six reports to write out at the end of each month, and the Diary I think is one that I might be relieved of. I am in school daily except Saturdays, so what can I put in it. I will submit a diary of the Saturday work with an expense account, as Saturdays are the only day on which I can get into town to make any purchase that is necessary. This would make a little less work at the end of the month. It could be observed that Farmer Lepine of One Arrows whose diary I have often had to read over while at Duck Lake take the first, or last day of the month to write his monthly report, while in my case I have various accounts and correspondence to attend to besides a day in school.

In order to obtain the Tuesday mail without being out after dark my wife has been teaching the girls sewing and knitting during the
The health of the people has been good, & my wife & I generally manage to get around to visit each house about once a month, while more frequent visits have been made when necessary to those sick.

An accident occurred to a young girl, Nina Smith by name, some six weeks ago hurting her knee by falling out of a rig. Dr Strong visited her, and at first could not locate the difficulty, some three weeks later his partner Dr MacMillan came out, and said at once it would be necessary for the girl to go to the hospital for an operation. At first I would not allow this until authority had been obtained, and it was only on the strict understanding that the Doctor should go at once to Mr Chisholm and wire for authority that I allowed him to take the girl in. I am informed by the Agent that this was not done, but what could I do at the time. The Doctor said it was necessary that the girl should go at once, and by promising to take the matter up with Mr Chisholm I thought that this would be the most satisfactory way out of the difficulty. I may add that the girl has since undergone a serious operation on the knee joint. I called at the Hospital last time I was in town, & found her making fair progress.

The threshing outfit recently purchased worked very well, and completed threshing operations in good time. The people are now using the engine with the circular saw loaned them from the Agency Headquarters so that the gasoline engine and circular saw are in competition against the old Hudson Bay axe.

I also enclose some photographs of the school etc., taken by myself, that may be of interest.

Sir,

With reference to my recent report on the school in which I stated that in was with no small amount of difficulty that I am able to give same the attention it should have on account of the morning chores I think I have found a way to overcome this, which I would ask for the Departments approval.

My statement may be misunderstood. I like to be fresh when going into school in the morning, I am sure I could do better work, but this at present is impossible on account to the chores. Milking, feeding & watering, carrying in wood & water besides cleaning the stable take a little over an hour, and I cannot teach in stable clothes.

To get over this, I am desirious of giving half my rations to an Indian, Francis Dreaver, by name who is willing to do an hours work here in the mornings, if the Department can do something in connection with the old Farmers house. Dreaver is an old man at present on the monthly ration list, I think just about able to do what I need. He has three children attending school, this family being the longest distance away, quite four miles. Now if Dreaver could be permitted to occupy the old Farm house he could assist me, and at the same time have his children quite close to school which would be a very excellent arrangement.

Unfortunately the farmhouse is occupied by another man, by name Alfred Smith, who moved in there this fall with the permission of the Agent and who promptly left the big gate always open causing myself & the Agent a whole lot of work in connection with the cattle getting into our stacks.

This man is married, but has no family, and I notice is often away for several days at the time. He had a house of his own, but I am
informed that when he was allowed to move into the Farmhouse, he sold his own building to a half-breed, Willie Umpherville, who has lived for some time on the reserve.

If the Department could see fit to instruct the Agent to move out Smith, and allow Dreaver to live there, it would be of a very great assistance to myself, & I am sure benefit the school, also help Dreaver, besides being at no cost to the Head office.

There are plenty of empty houses in fair condition that Smith could use, also it might be used as a means of getting rid of the halfbreed Umpherville. Of course I know that this man has no right to live on the reserve, but the fact remains, that having done so for a good many years now, to turn him out is liable to cause unpleasantness for myself & Agent with Chief John Smith & his family to whom the man is related. I cannot say that Umpherville causes trouble by bringing whiskey onto the reserve, but he farms a field, sells hay & wood, used the Threshing outfit, all of which are resented by the Phillip Bear & Crain families.

Under these circumstances I trust that my suggestion may have consideration and some instructions may be forwarded to the Agent. I would add that it is only during the winter, the dark mornings I feel the rush, also Dreaver complains of the distance & cold for his children to attend school during the short days.

Yours truly,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of 19th ultimo, No. 117084-1, with reference to Alfred Smith occupying the old farmhouse on John Smith's reserve, I have the honour to inform you that the said Alfred Smith is an Indian, and a son of Chief John Smith of that reserve.

When visiting the reserve last fall with Mr. Inspector Chisholm, Chief John Smith asked me permission to allow his son, Alfred, who has no house of his own, to spend the winter in the old farmhouse which was unoccupied. The same evening we saw Alfred, who made the request personally. I asked Mr. Inspector Chisholm what his opinion was. He replied that he saw no reason why the young man could not spend the winter in the house, seeing that it was unoccupied. I remarked at the time that the house had already been occupied by Indians, namely, Gilbert Bear, carpenter, who was living in the house when I took office, and spent the winter 1912-13 there. I then told Alfred Smith that he could winter there, but that he was to give it up at any time should we need it for someone else, or for other purposes. I have written Smith telling him to

to vacate the house at once in order that it may be available for Francis Dreaver's use.

Dear Sir,

Will you allow me to write you again personally, as in so doing, I feel more assured that my letter will have proper consideration.

I regret to state that I have been laid up in bed for the past two weeks with a sharp attack of Peritonitis, & have only this morning got up for the first time. On account of this I had to close the school on the 9th instant, & hire a man to go to Birch Hills for Dr Giles whom I had to send for again last Sunday. I have also had to hire a man to do the outside chores, feeding the animals, etc., or rather I had to get the eldest schoolboy as most of the men are away hunting. When I hired the lad on the 9th, I promised him $1.25 per day with dinner, as I did not think I would need him more than three days at the very most, otherwise it would have been cheaper and more satisfactory to have got a man for a couple of weeks. I am very sorry that it was quite impossible to ask permission from Duck Lake to hire anyone, and I am now at a loss to know if I might be permitted to put this expense in my monthly expenses account, or not. It will come to $16. or $18. that is if I can get out by next Monday which I hope to do.

I would like to inform you the direct cause of this attack. For the past six weeks I have been plagued with a dozen pigs from the nearest Indians house, who have lived on the Departments Cat stacks they have been here all time, I have chased & chased, and fixed gates and fixed gates, I have spoken to the Indian when he has been at home, which is not often, and I have shown the damage to the Indian Agent, I have repaired the gate the Indian gent made me at
the time the cattle got into the stacks several times, & it has been impossible to keep them out. Altogether I consider the cattle destroyed one stack, and the pigs another.

Now, on the 6th inst., I had to go to Prince Albert and while there called on Mr Chisholm to see what could be done in the matter of fencing the whole of the buildings with proper fencing this spring and this matter of the pigs in the stacks came up. He showed me a way which I might fix to keep them out for the present. On my return I found my wife had been chasing these pigs again, and on Saturday I worked all day at the job. It was a bitter cold day somewhere round about 30 below with a keen wind, and I caught cold. I am certain of this, I felt at the time I would feel the effects of that days work. I was not, either successful, in keeping the pigs out, and on Sunday I asked the Carpenter to come a fix a proper gate which he did at a cost of $2.50. This could have been done last fall, and the oats as well as a lot of work to myself saved.

Under these circumstances I feel I am justified in asking the Department to pay the expense of having a man also for the one who went for Dr Giles. The Doctor will, I expect send me an account of $15.00 or $20.00 at least which I suppose I will have to stand although I feel this also is something that the Department have let me in for.

I must also say that if the Department expect one man to do all the work here it is absolutely necessary to have everything arranged as conveniently as possible. If the Department cannot fence the buildings with proper suitable fencing to keep out the animals this spring, then I must decline to be responsible for the stacks.

I cannot refrain from remarking that it seems to be most foolish to grow anything here under the present circumstances. Last year I called attention to this matter of fencing both to Mr Chisholm.
and Mr Schmidt. The Department went to a large expense putting in and harvesting the oat crop, and also a big expense was incurred in growing potatoes for the school. The cattle of the reserve are allowed all over the field, and the stacks built in a place where the cattle can feed at. The potatoes are planted where the cattle and pigs can tramp them and eat off the young plants, and in consequence the Department have to buy potatoes now, and will shortly have to buy oats.

I trust you will be able to grant authority for the expenditure incurred during the past ten days, and I do hope that the Department will see that it would save a great deal of work and worry, and be more satisfactory in every way to have proper fences made.

Yours truly,

D.C. Scott, Esq.
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your favour of the 28th ultimo No 117384-1 with reference to the employment of a man here during my recent illness. In reply, I cannot refrain from stating that your letter more than astonishes me, more especially as I understood from the Agent that he had authority to employ a man here whenever it was necessary.

It would appear from your letter that I am desirous of getting the Department to pay for a man who has been doing some work for myself personally, such as keeping my own furnace fired, and it may have been considered that if the school was closed there would have been no need of a labourer. If this is the case I beg to point out that the Departments conclusions are wrong, and to say that the man was employed feeding the Departments horse, watering, twice a day, cleaning the stable & drawing out to the field, and the same respecting my own cow. I own the cow I must say, but the Department own a "Farmers' cow here which with the Agents permission has been loaned to one of the best Indians, as I do not need two.

I also wish to say, that I was taken ill on Monday Feb. 9th, but thinking that same would only be a passing cold which would only last a couple of days, I did not employ a man until Thursday the 13th. I fed, watered & cleaned the stable myself on the Tuesday morning while feeling very sick. On the Wednesday my wife, & the girl employed to help with the childrens meal attended to the stack as I could not get up. On the Thursday I sent the girl out to find
man as my wife had been up all night, and I might add from that day till the following Sunday she did not sleep at all, and could hardly leave my room.

As the Department is aware, or should be aware, I have the horse here in connection with the Farmers work, & I would like to ask, under such circumstances as these, who was expected to look after the animal. Do you think that my wife should have done the chores morning and evening, and nurse myself at the same time because if this is so I beg to state that under no circumstances will I have my wife feeding animals & cleaning stables. Would it have been satisfactory if no attention had been paid to the stable at all. What attitude would the Department have taken if the animals had been left tied in the stable for ten days? also if the matter of obtaining authority from the Agent before hand is held to, I must point out that from Tuesday until the following Saturday there is no way of communicating with Duck Lake, and then the reply would take four days to come back. What would the Department have me do in the meantime?

I also wish to again draw attention to the fact that my illness was caused by attending to the Departments work & not my own. I have several times commented on the fact that the present arrangements respecting the fencing here is most unsatisfactory, I have shown Mr Chisholm how the Indians cattle get into the stacks, & Mr Schmidt has seen a dozen pigs feeding on the Departments oats. All the winter I have had all my spare time occupied in trying to save the feed provided, last summer it was impossible to have a garden. Both the Agent and Inspector have been here and seen how difficult the arrangements are for a man alone, & surely I have written the Head Office enough on the subject.

I may also point out that the Department have never spent a cent in making proper outdoor arrangements for one
John Smith's Reserve, Puckahn,
Saskatchewan.

man to do the work of the farmer, and the school at the same time.

Mr Agent Macarthur just before he left, had the stable moved over here from the Farmhouse for which the Department paid for, but this is all. The fencing and stackyard & garden have only been of a makeshift nature made by Mr Macdougalls boys, as both the Agent & Inspector can see. I also wish to say that one of the difficulties that arose between the Agent & Mr Macdougall was the fact that the latter employed an Indian on every possible occasion with, or without authority, when rough work had to be done, and to point out that I have not yet employed a man without permission, doing a great deal of the labour myself. I have daily drawn the manure from the stable into the field, while last year it was piled outside, and a man & team employed a couple of days in the spring to take it away. I have broken up bacon boxes to fix the stable walls, while in the past a man has been employed plastering. I have fixed fences & gates till I am tired, and in every way, when I have been able to make a repair myself, I have done so.

I must also add that the man employed recently was not kept one day longer than necessary. I was able to get up on Thursday the 19th, and was out on Sunday the 22nd, and I require the matter to have further consideration, also while I am able to teach and get around I do not yet feel fully recovered, and in event of my falling sick again I would be glad if the Department would inform me, by returning mail, how to proceed.

Dear Sir,

On January 20th last you forwarded me a communication numbered 117084 with reference to the old Farm house close by, the result of which I was able to hire an old Indian to help me during the winter months. I regret to say that this man recently left me claiming that the farm house was impossible to keep warm during the cold weather, which is probably correct.

With the short days I find that it is necessary to have someone, and I beg to submit a brief account of an arrangement made to overcome this difficulty which I hope the Department will approve of, also if possible allow something towards the expense.

I have hired a young Indian, one of the hunters, about 22 years of age who would have hunted this winter if the fur market had been satisfactory for the sum of $16.00 per month, half my rations, one room with a big stove in the farmhouse & dinners five days a week, for which, I am having the stable attended too night & morning, wood drawn up & placed in position for four stoves, schoolroom swept, fire lighted, furnaces cleaned & kept full with water, and various other jobs of such a nature, which I count as being my own chores, that task would occupy me upward of a couple of hours night & morning.

In addition to these things I am also having the man convey the children to and from school, the expense of which is included in the above mentioned sum. I will undertake for the time being.

I would like to point out however that my chores alone are hardly enough to warrant me keeping a man on my own account the whole day, while on the other hand if the man drives the children morning & evening, the middle part of the day would be well occupied. At present...
John Smith's Reserve, Puckahn, Saskatchewan.

present his day is occupied in the following manner.

He feeds and waters the horse & my cow at 8 o'clock, lights the schoolhouse fire & sweeps, then goes for the children about 20 minutes past eight, arriving with the first lot about ten past nine, then he goes to the north end of the reserve getting back about a quarter to ten. He then splits wood, and draws same up to my own house & schoolhouse, cleans the stable which occupies him till noon.

This afternoon he put part of a hay stack that had tumbled over into the loft, and one afternoon a week I can send him for the mail which will receive me of two hours, & have also a quantity of beef to cut up & I can keep him well occupied during the next month from 1st till 3rd at which time he takes the first lot of children home.

He finishes his day about 5.30, and I would like the Department to consider the matter of the expense. I think the man's time could be fairly divided evenly between driving the children to school and chores, and I am anxious to pay my share, half, if the Department will pay the other half, or the sum of $32.00 for drawing the children to school from the present date till March 18th of next year.

Such an arrangement, is in every way most satisfactory. I am able to give better attention to the school, and the other business of the reserve. The school attendance will be more satisfactory, and there will be times that instead of hiring outside labour I can use this man without additional expense. The horse will have to be kept here in any case, and he may as well do this as not, also it is in a manner providing for one of the Indians who would have a hard living during the winter.
