Sir,

I have to submit herewith a report on the work of the children attending the Day School here, also the reserve in general, during the past year.

With a smaller number of children of schoolage I find that the average attendance has been well maintained during the year, in fact it is slightly higher than last year, and seeing that all the children are small, I think this can be considered satisfactory.

I consider the younger children have made the most marked progress during the year. They are able to read from the Primer also write, and do addition. I find that I have put in considerable time on this younger class, using a supply of Kindergarten materials but, in comparison with the elder children, I think their advancement will be more rapid in the future especially in Arithmetic and Reading.

I find now that I have still a younger class, some eight little boys between the age of six and eight, whom it is difficult to keep busy, but I hope to do something with these during the coming year.

Respecting the older children, these have been by no means neglected. Advancement has been made by the boys in Arithmetic & Reading, they write well, and have regular lessons in Geography Composition, & Canadian History, as also do the girls. One of the boys Leonard Bear is considerably in advance of the others, and there would be no difficulty for this boy to pass the Matriculation if I could give him the time. Unfortunately with such a number of small children, it is almost impossible to give ones time to one pupil to any great extent. The Department could make a splendid man
out of this little fellow if he could be sent away from his home,
which I regret to say cannot be considered satisfactory.

A sample of the children's work is being forwarded, in which
Leonard Bears' work will be noted. The samples are part of an
exhibit shown during the summer in the school.

On November 4th Mr. Thibodeau and Mr. Schmidt inspected the
school, but as they were only in the room from 3:10 till 3:50 in
the afternoon, an extensive inspection was not made. These
gentlemen caused me considerable annoyance at the time. They
arrived on a mail day, when I have a standing arrangement with
the clergyman to give a Scripture lesson during the last 30 minutes
and although I explained this the evening before, this was
upset, and in the end, the children had to be dismissed as it was
too dark to see. However, both seemed satisfied with what was being
done.

Before dealing with my Overseers report, and the Matrons'
report, I must preface these with a note on the Whiskey Traffic,
as the whole of the work, also ex-pupils is affected by the above.

I cannot express myself strongly enough, over the seemingly
indifference on the part of the Department to this business, &
the only excuse I can find must be in the fact that the harm
and expense caused by this cannot be fully grasped, except by
the man in direct contact with the Indians. I know the matter is
a difficult one, but that should not allow these people to go on
year after year, pulling down everything done for them by the
Department and Church in other directions, as the whiskey does.

The land is excellent, their health good, and this reserve
would be entirely self-supporting in a few years if the whiskey
business in the City of Prince Albert could be controlled as
regards Indians, which it is not. During the year I have had
brought before me different cases, in detail, which for various
reasons I have been directed to drop. The Hotels, Wholesale stores,
The Hudson Bay Co all sell, almost openly according to the Indians.
I have reason to believe, speak truthfully. Recently the north part of Saskatchewan was placed under prohibition, the line being drawn three miles north of Prince Albert. One of my older Indians stated recently that considering that Prince Albert is a noted gathering place for Indians, it was a pity that the City was not included in the prohibition district.

Respecting the farming operations of the people during the year, I must state that the crop was not so good as last year, a bad hail storm in July flattened the grain over one half of the reserve, and the whole potato crop was badly frozen. I have been able several times to visit the fields, and as stated, if the money did not go in drinking these people would have all the machinery they needed. Hay has been plentiful and commands a good price, while the cattle sold during the first week of the war brought them record prices. This annual cattle sale is not considered by some very satisfactory.

Two days before the cattle sale Mr N. Russell, a cattle buyer of Prince Albert, visited some of the houses telling the people that he had received permission from the Agent to buy all he could, as no other buyers would be coming, and in consequence of this several of them sold to Mr Russell, which resulted in a great deal of confusion and trouble. One of the results being a dispute between one of the Indians regarding the ownership of an animal, which is being looked into at the present time. Mr Schmidt maintains that no permission was given to Mr Russell, who on the other hand maintains that he was in the right. However, the whole affair was most unsatisfactory, & it is to be hoped, will not occur again.

The breakdown of the threshing outfit was caused by some of the Indians refusing to pay the men who can run the outfit, and getting all the young men of the reserve around the engine with wrenches trying to make it go. As I have no authority to prevent this, or settle the dispute that had arisen over wages, the outfit had to be laid up until the Agent could visit the reserve.
During the latter part of the year, an offer of seed grain for the coming season was made, but owing to a misunderstanding the Indians did not hear of same until after freeze up. I hope some seed grain can be issued. (On the other hand there is money for Whiskey to-morrow but seed grain will be wanted).

In common with other reserves the fur market is low, but I do not see any suffering on account of this.

In connection with the Farm work I must call attention to a unsatisfactory state of affairs that occurs with the ex-pupils between the ages of 16 and 22. We have several young men of this age well able to read & write etc., anxious to make a start, but who seem to have no location. I have heard of cases when some of these young fellows wanted to plow the dispute of land has arisen so strong that they have given up the idea. A large amount of land is being held idle in this way, by the older men, and something should be done to decide on locations for these young men. At present I cannot urge them to do much, as they say at once that don't know where they can make a start. They work out, or drop into idle ways, & start drinking, and on this account a good deal of money spent on education is wasted. Some kind of control over these ex-pupils for five years after they leave school is very desirable.

In dealing with the Patrons work, regarding which a complaint was received last week I must point out that the monthly reports submitted have been the same as those sent in by Mrs Macdougall, and also by ourselves while at La Corne in 1912. Reports of this nature also passed through my hands while at Duck Lake, and it is somewhat out of the way to request detailed information on this subject monthly before the actual requirements of the Department have been made known. The Circular for our guidance shows a lack of experience on the part of the writer, and it must be remembered I cannot compel the Indians to do everything the Department desires, also many of the instructions contained therein are not carried out.
in many homes of the surrounding settlers whom the Indians meet
and it cannot be expected that the Indians will go more along these
lines than their neighbours. I would refer for instance to
the use of the river water for drinking. Halfbreed & white settlers
up and down the river have always used river water without boiling
often drawing same from the same place at which the cattle drink, and
it would be exceeding difficult to get them to do otherwise. The
rule respecting the placing a clean sheet on the floor for the baby
to play on would not be done except I remained in the houses. They
would scrub their floors more often rather than do this. The matter
of ventilation is always a difficult subject, not only with Indians
but with Canadians, during the winter. Double windows on without being
made to open as a general rule throughout Western Canada is also
noticed by the Indians, who, when building fix their windows solid.

There can be no ventilation through the schoolhouse windows
for instance, with the double windows on. To overcome this I have
kept off the centre double window, so that it is possible to get
fresh air.

On the other hand these people are much more advanced than
other reserves. They are clean, and have proper outhouses, and most
of them can get me a decent meal if I call, with a table cloth
and clean knives etc. The work of the women on the farms is creditable;
they make good butter, etc., etc., and many of them can pluck and clean
a chicken much better than one sees displayed for sale in the Prince
Albert stores today. Poultry keeping is made to pay by several.
The manner in which the midday meal for the children is served is in itself a lesson for them, everything being kept clean and in proper order as it should be, while this house is always spotless, and an example which does not fail to impress them. The influence of the school also reflects in their homes, the difference being easily noted between those families whom have children attending, and those in which the children are too young. I find that all the children change their clothes after school, and they are always clean and tidy.

Regarding the note requiring instruction to be given in cooking and sewing I must say it would be almost impossible for my wife to undertake the former during the morning, but frequent instruction is given when visiting the sick, along these lines. With regard to the sewing it will be interesting to note that on Wednesday afternoons since August a number of the women have met in the dinning room sewing or rather knitting socks for the Red Cross Society, several of them providing their own materials. Previous to this they met under my wife's guidance for the purpose of making children's clothes which they sold among themselves for the Church funds. The women's weekly sewing meetings has been a long established thing, and a small control over the young women & girls who have left school is thus retained.

There seems to have been a misunderstanding with the agent over the supply of drugs, but I would point out that the accounts submitted are much smaller than in former years. There is however a case of expenditure which I would like to draw attention to, in
which I can show might have been saved, had I been consulted.

Mina Smith, a schoolgirl between fifteen & sixteen years of age in October of 1913 had an accident which resulted in her being in the hospital all last winter. The result of being in company with an elder sister mixed up in a drunken brawl north of the river at Prince Albert this spring she had to go again to the hospital and have a leg taken off. The Department then provided her with a cork leg, which she did not want, and does not use. The Agent tells me he knows nothing of this case, and I have no correspondence upon the subject beyond reporting the accident in the first place to Duck Lake. Whoever authorised this expenditure did not give the matter much thought, which seems strange to us, when such a fuss is made over the smallest unauthorised accounts.

In the future, however the Matrons report will be more detailed.

I find that I have gone to considerable expense during the year in connection with different things that should not have been a call on my pocket. School materials, kindergarten, reading books & music have cost upward of ten Dollars; the clay from the cellar of this house was still in the yard making the place a regular mudhole between the house and stable, I have had removed at a cost of eight dollars, hay & oats provided in small amounts, & different small payments made to Indians which I have had to make being without authority at the time. These however with the exception of the school material, have enabled me to considerably improve the appearance.
I must add, however, these small items are not so extensive as to request repayment, but some might have been carried out by the Agent had they been noticed.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

I have to thank you for your letter No 117084/1 of the 16th ultimo, respecting the attendance of the school children.

In reply, I must say that your letter arrived after I had already provided prizes, and school attendance medals, as attached, and I do not think further rewards are necessary at present.

I am, however, asking Messrs Eaton's of Winnipeg for a detailed account, or failing this a statement of some kind, of the goods obtained from them for the above purpose, and when this is received if the Department will forward me a cheque for $10.00, I will use same to purchase a Silver attendance Shield, which will form an attendance competition for a few years, the same to be held for a year by the pupil making the highest attendance. I promised the small shields, that have been given, last Christmas, and I think that a large shield which they can hang on the walls will still further improve the attendance during the coming year.

At the Christmas Tree Concert held on the 23rd, the children collected from their parents the sum of $7.35, which they desire to give you with a request that same should be sent to the Red Cross Societies Fund for wounded Canadian Soldiers, etc., etc., and postal notes for this amount is enclosed herewith.

I trust both these matters will be satisfactory,

Yours truly,

I have the honour to inform you that Mr. P.H. Gentleman, teacher at John Smith's reserve is again asking for a man to assist him during the coming winter, on arrangements similar to those of the winter 1914-15.

The man does Mr. Gentleman's chores, which consist of attending to one horse and cow, splitting and carrying in wood which is already cut in stove lengths, and drives the children living along the River road to and from the school with the Department horse and rig.

I do not recommend this expenditure, as I do not consider it necessary.

Regarding the conveying of the children, I do not see that the average attendance is any larger when driven. The children who are driven are well able to walk as the road along the river is always good, and the farthest away are only about one and a half miles, with houses every quarter mile along the road where they can warm, if cold.

The Department horse, which is on the reserve for the use of the Overseer, is an old one, and will not stand the driving all winter; he is very quiet and suitable for Mr. Gentleman, who does very little driving other than going for the mail four miles away, and making a few calls with Mrs. Gentleman when she goes out as Field Matron.

If the children have to be driven with the Department horse and—

horse and rig a new outfit will have to be provided.

When visiting the reserve during the fall of 1913 with Inspector Chisholm, this matter was discussed thoroughly by the Inspector, Mr. Gentleman and myself, and reported upon by me on Nov. 5th, 1913, file No. 115, which brought me in reply letter No. 117084/1 dated Nov. 17th of the same year.

Last fall when visiting the reserve with the Inspector the question again came up, Mr. Gentleman asking for a man to do his chores, go for the mail and drive the children with the Department outfit. This was not approved of by the Inspector nor myself as we did not see the necessity for conveying the children any more than winter than the previous winters, and the engaging of a labourer to do Mr. Gentleman's chores was not considered at all necessary.

Mr. Gentleman, according to his own statement to me, then took the matter up with the Bishop of Saskatchewan, telling his Lordship that he must get him a man or get someone else on the job; the result being, he claims, Department letter No. 117084-1, dated Nov. 30th, 1914, informing me that $32.00 would be paid to an Indian for driving the children to and from school until the 18th of March, 1915.

In my opinion, and I feel certain that I am right, it is not the conveying of the children that interests Mr. Gentleman, but the doing of his chores; and when it comes to that point I cannot recommend the engaging of a man to do same.

I am informing Mr. Gentleman that I am not recommending the employment of a man to help him, and would ask the Department to consider the whole matter should he correspond direct to headquarters.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Non-treaty pupils, two boys one girl. One of these boys Julius Crain and one girl Bloomfield are living with relatives on the reserve and attend school. The other boy, C. Price, lives with his grandfather or Uncle near the reserve. The John Smith Day School is the nearest school for him to attend. There is a public school in that district but it is rather far away for him as his grandfathers house is on the north east corner of the school district.

Should these children be allowed to attend our school? If not, they will probably never see the inside of a school again. The teacher does not complain of these children attending but finds his work heavy. With these pupils attending he has found his average as high as 30 for one week. Of these 30, twelve are very young beginners who will not attend regularly this winter. Next spring they will be able to do so but on the other hand I expect 7 of the older pupils will stop going to school as they will be 16 years or over. I would like to know the Department's regulations in regard to these non-treaty children. If granted the privilege of attending our day schools, it will also mean allowing them to live and grow up on the reserve where they will expect to make a home in future. It may also cause numbers of others to do so at the Butler, Coxby and Glen Mary settlements, situated between John and James Smith Reserves, and mostly settled by half-breeds who are relatives of the Indians on the said reserves. If it is going to make a precedent, which will be followed immediately on the James Smith reserve, I would not recommend that they be allowed to attend.

Dear Sir,

I very much regret to find that I must ask the Department to give me some consideration with regards the question of having a man to help me during the winter months.

I assure you that if I could possibly manage without one, or even undertake to pay a man out of my salary, I would do so, as I have no desire to make expense, but I think if the Department knew the many things one has to do between daylight & dark in the short days, there would be no objection to an allowance of a small amount.

Might I be allowed to submit the following for consideration, but beforehand I may add that if an allowance for this purpose has not been estimated for, etc., etc., I will try to do the best I can during the winter. The Department seem to manage as much as they are able, & with these very expensive times, one must be prepared to work harder.

From the attached letter from Duck Lake, you will notice that I have already had some correspondence upon the subject with the Agent, who has not seen fit to recommend same. Early in October I asked the Agent to take up this matter with you, and gave him the details of the children attending school etc., and I was under the impression that he intended to do so. My reason for dealing
with the subject of having the children conveyed to school and a man to help me under the same heading is that by having the one man for both purposes seems to be the most satisfactory, and certainly cheaper. The Department will remember that last year a man was employed for this, and that he was paid $16.00 a month, of which I paid half, and greater part of my own rations. I hoped that this arrangement might have been made this winter, although I must say that it would have been somewhat of a difficulty for me to pay half, and I trusted a good deal upon an increased attendance of young children hoping on account of this that you could undertake the whole amount. On the 16th of November the Agent was here, and on that day he told me that you had not replied to his request for a man, in spite of his letter being written on the 11th, which I did not receive until the 20th. I had in mind some previous instructions from the Department to the effect that I should take up these matters with the Agent, which I did, allowing plenty of time for consideration, but which you will see has resulted in considerable delay, making things very difficult for me just at the time a man is needed.

In October I was able to point out to the Agent that there are five or six young children who have been coming to school during the summer, one or two of which attended a few days last winter, while driven, but which could not be expected to attend during this winter if they had to walk in the deep snow.
I find that the total attendance during November has been 462 compared with 555 during October. It may be partly accounted for by a form of Chicken-pox which Dr Giles tells me some of the children have (he has ordered them kept at home on account of this) but on looking over the register I notice that nearly all the young children are away, and I account for this owing to a big fall of snow we had in the middle of the month, since which the younger children have not attended. The statement of the Agent to the effect that it is up to the Indians to see that their children attend school can hardly be said to apply to the little ones, also they do see that the elder ones attend, and they want to send the little ones, but they say they are so long on the road, under the present arrangement, and some of them have already asked me to take up this matter with you, one man going as far as to say that he would have no difficulty in getting a partition signed by the parents for the Department's consideration on this subject.

It seems to me, that while the Indians are anxious to send the younger children, it is a pity not to do something for them. They state that years ago when other children were not so young they were driven, also they appear to think that it is done in the Carlton Agency. Of course I do not know if they are right or wrong in this respect. I notice however that the driving of the children has a very good effect on the reserve in general, in other ways than one might expect. I fancy that when they know there will
rig along the road at a certain time everyone is up earlier. These people would not care for their neighbours to say that such and such a child could not go to school because they got up too late, and thus in a way, the matter may have other points of advantage which we have not considered.

As regards the outfit for this work, as the Agent says it may necessitate some expense. It is too much for the single horse I have now; there are too many children, but it could be managed if desired. I have in mind that throughout the Agency some of the Farm Instructors have two teams, if not more. Mr McCloy recently at La Corne, told me a short while ago that when he left there, there were six or seven horses there, but in any case it cannot be possible that all these teams are working during the winter, and I don't think it would be a matter of great difficulty to transfer me a team, sleigh & double harness from another reserve, for the winter months. Oats would be an outlay, but these horses have to be fed in any case. The only employment the teams can be put to during the winter months by Instructors largely consists of hauling rations from town about once in two months, and I am sure one of them one of them would haul in enough to last over the winter, and release a team if required to do so beforehand.

In this manner I think the outfit could be found without purchasing anything, and by having a man employed the children can be convoyed, & I can have the remainder of his time during the day. He would be
employed cleaning stable, drawing in wood for two furnaces & two stoves, and taking away ashes. Cutting up winter beef for rations which I receive in quarters & have to cut into twenty pound joints. Drawing in water for house & school furnace, which with a pump that needs priming several times daily, is several minutes work. My oat bin is in the old schoolhouse, and once a week oats have to be carried to the stable. He could have placed the storm windows & doors on the house & schoolhouse, and in numerous other ways his time could be occupied. Wood will shortly have to be sawn & split and I really don't know who I can get to do it.

All this I have to do before and after school hours, & when you consider that it is not light before seven & is beginning to get dark soon after four, it can be seen that it is difficult to manage everything without working after dark. This is labourers work & with a large school, I think these things might be considered. During the summer months when the days are long, I do not mind, but at this time of the year when many extra things have to be done it is very hard.

I would add that when the Agent has requested the regular estimates in the summer months I have included this allowance, but I do not know if same has been passed or not.

I am sorry that this letter is so lengthy, but I have gone into details fully, as I think same would be required for consideration, which I trust it may receive,

Dear Sir;

I would be glad if you would ask the Department without delay, if they will allow the school to be closed for the first two weeks in January next; reopening of the 16th of that month and going on until July, 13th. This will give us two weeks of the summer holidays during the winter.

I gather from the Indians that they would rather have a longer holiday for the children just after Christmas, and shorter in the summer, on account of the very cold weather that we usually have at that time. The little boys cannot, or do not come well in the cold weather, and with two months holiday in the summer they miss a good many days. The days also are short, and two weeks in January will give me some time to draw up the rest of the wood, and cut up the beef, and besides this there would be a small saving on wood.

I also wish to be allowed to arrange the Easter holidays according to the weather. Easter comes just about the time the snow is going and I notice that school has to continue while the road is almost impossible to travel for about a week, for water. Several of the children miss these days, then perhaps during the Easter holiday the road will be dry. It would be better if their Easter holiday could be given them just while the snow is going. They get wet feet causing colds, etc., and I think we should arrange this better. Of course this Easter Holiday would depend upon the weather entirely, but the children would not miss so many days if I could be allowed to arrange it as desired.

Neither of these requests would make any difference to the total number of school days in the year.

Yours truly,

(Signed) P.H. Gentleman.

Dear Sir,

I must thank you for your letter of June 30th last No. 117084 allowing two weeks holiday, which was spent in British Columbia.

Both my wife and I are so charmed with that part of Canada that I am anxious to know if the Department could transfer us to the charge of a Boarding school, in that province, when an opening should occur. Dear Sir:

In making out my school report for the September quarter I have to report that two children have not attended since the holidays, and as their absence has arisen out of certain circumstances I wish the Department to have the full details of the matter, and also to ask that some instructions be given dealing with matters that have arisen regarding these absences.

The two children are Sophia Crain, 14½, daughter of Geo. Crain, and Kate Crain, 12½, daughter of James Crain.

As you know, some of the people recently asked for a change of teacher, a request that they also made of the Bishop of Saskatchewan, while I was away in B.C. On my return the Bishop and I went into the matter, and I found that the list of names sent to him was mainly not those of parents of children attending school.

The Bishop suggested that I see the parents, and that if they wished for a change, or if there was any decided opinion that a change was desired on the parents part, then some arrangements might be made, otherwise it would be better for us to remain.

This I did. I saw all the parents, and asked them to meet me in the schoolhouse, and I told them that if they wished for a change I had no particular desire to remain, as the children would make no progress whatever under such conditions. I found that the objections to my work came from James and George Crain. Three other parents who had signed the request to the Bishop said that they had done so, after being requested several times by James Crain. The majority of the parents objected to a change, and gave their opinions freely upon the matter, and it was clear that the difficulties had
been brought about by James Crain. The same day, I received in the mail the Department's letter on the same subject addressed to the Chief, who was present that evening at my request, with the other councillor. I gave the Chief his letter, of course not knowing its contents, and on its being interpreted, there arose considerable discussion in Cree. To quieten matters down, I suggested that if the Chief would give me the letter I might be able to explain it, for which he thanked me, as he could not understand same himself.

I saw at once that a request for a change had been made, but the discussion had arisen over the fact that the Chief, and James Crain, and apparently the north end of the reserve had written you without consulting the other Councillor, or the rest of the band. I then explained to them that, as the Chief, and some of them had made this request to the Department, that as stated, enquiries would now most certainly be made, and that probably the Agent, or Inspector or both, would shortly pay us a visit, at which time they would have an opportunity to go fully into the subject. Of course, this might have been a mistake on my part, but at the time, I could see no other way out of the difficulty, and I certainly expected this to happen. However, everyone was satisfied to let it remain at this.

Somewhat to my surprise, no further notice has been taken, although the Department tell the Chief, that he would be informed later upon the subject. During the last week in August, I visited all the houses, and told the people to return the children to school on the third of September, which they have done with the two exceptions mentioned. After two weeks of school, I heard that James and Geo Crain had sent their children to one of the public schools in Prince Albert, and not know what attitude would be taken on the matter, or if the attendance of these children at school in Prince Albert was a fact or not, I reported the above details to Mr Crombie.
with a request that he should pay us a visit, or ask Mr Schmidt to do so in order that the people might, at least, have the satisfaction of knowing that the matter had, or would be enquired into. Mr Crombie writes me that he has already given his views upon the subject, but whatever these might be, it is hardly satisfactory to the parents, as from their point of view nothing has been done, either one way or the other.

A few days after this Mr Schmidt arrived, and on going into these matters with him, I found that he had had no correspondence upon the matter and regarding the Crain children going to school in town, we decided that I should see the Crains and tell them that this could not be allowed, and that the children must return to school as soon as possible. The next day I saw the mother of Kate Crain, a halfbreed woman, who told me that her daughter Kate was attending one of the town schools, but she would not tell me which, and also refused to attempt to get the girl back from town.

As it is impossible to believe them, the following Saturday, I met Mr G.A. Brown, the Superintendent of the Prince Albert schools, who told me that he would enquire if Kate Crain was attending any of the town schools, and he now writes that he cannot trace her. I gathered from him that the town schools would not be anxious for her, but as she might be working in the town, it would be difficult to refuse her admission unless requested to do so by the Department.

On the other hand, James Crain has told everyone that his daughter is attending a town school, and he tells Gilbert Bear H.M. that he intends to keep her there. I reported my interview with Mr Brown to Mr Crombie, with a request that some steps be taken, but at the time of writing I have not had his reply.

During the past two weeks James Crain has endeavored to have the parents of three other girls, aged between ten and twelve, send their children into town, and in this way seems to be anxious to create disfaction among the parents, but so far he has not met with
success. At the same time, such proceedings do not tend to help
the school in anyway. James Crain has also a boy of nine who attends,
but whom I think does so with the express intention of making as much
trouble as possible; and as all the people are aware of these circumstances, it causes an entirely unsatisfactory tone to our work.

I hope you will see fit to back me up in some shape or form; either
insist that James Crain returns his children, or dismiss them entirely.
I believe you are aware that this band have in the past given various
troubles and difficulties to whoever has been in charge. Former Agent
MacArthur told me in 1913 that I would stay with them six months, and he
knew them well, but with tact I have managed them since that time, and
I trust the Crains can be informed that such things as these cannot be
allowed. If no notice is taken, it reflects upon a whole host of
other things, such as killing of cattle, and selling without a permit,
thus making other rules and regulations most difficult to enforce.

I might also take this opportunity to thank you for your letter
No 117084-1 dated August 18th, and while these people have little, if
any cause to complain and most of them would be satisfied if a firm
stand is taken upon the matter, my interest in the school is not what it
was, a change into a Boarding school when a vacancy occurs, is something
to look forward to.

Yours very truly

I must say that I want the Department to back me up, and have this girl sent back. I do not object to the child attending a town school, and am willing to work through the whole eight grades of the provincial course with the girl, but I do strongly object to the manner that Crain has taken the matter in his own hands, for if he allowed to do so, others will want to follow his example, and I do not feel that it is correct that I should do the elementary work

I am sorry that this matter has not been settled before this. I do not like the influence she will bring back with her, but in order that the rest of the band may know that they cannot take matters entirely in their own hands, her return is necessary.

Gilbert Bear H.M. also Robert Bear H.M./ tell me that that it would be satisfactory if a firm hand is shown; the Chief is indifferent. Crain sent his two elder girls, here, some years ago, removed them to Battleford, removed them from Battleford in less than a year, and kept them at home, until I came here when they made an attendance for about a year, and the man is known as a kicker among the other people.

Dear Sir;

For upward of a year or so, I have been thinking of writing to ask the Department if any consideration could be given to an application for an advance in salary.

My salary is the same as we received in 1913, while our work in one way or another seems to have increased. In addition to this prices on almost everything have greatly advanced within the past six months. Looking over lists of school material recently I find that these also have gone up. I make use of many little helps in the school at my own expense; footballs, baseballs etc all of which have taken an advance.

I also find that when I have occasion to employ an Indian that I have to pay them double that of two years ago. They are getting very high wages for outside farmers, which makes help both difficult and expensive to obtain. I have to get a man at times, more often during the winter months. In the past, I have often issued my own rations for help during the short days, but with the much higher price of flour and bacon, we are not able to afford to do this.

I also have to send part of my salary to England & I am told things are very high at home. In nearby schools salaries have almost doubled in the past two years, and in some cases houses for teachers have been built. Trusting the application will receive consideration.

Yours truly,

Sir,

John Smith's Reserve No. 99.
Overseer in Charge, P.H. Gentleman.

Mr. Gentleman is also teacher at the day school on the reserve. As overseer he is of very little assistance to me apart from the issuing of rations once a month to the destitute, seven in number and occasionally to some sick person. He is not handy with machinery and knows very little about cattle or horses. To the work of the Indians he gives very little attention, and none whatever to their cattle.

BUILDINGS.- The teacher's residence, schoolhouse and other buildings are convenient, and are kept in good repair.

YARDS and GARDEN,- The yards are kept clean and tidy, and the small garden in the school yard is growing nicely, and is kept clean.

MACHINERY,- There being no home farm on this reserve, we have no machinery. The Indians purchase their own implements and care for same at their homes. The band threshing machine is kept at the Teacher's home. This is a 12 horse Gasoline Engine and an Eclipse Separator. The engine is kept in an open shed and the separator is left outside, there being no room for same.

DEPARTMENT STOCK,- A driving horse for the use of the Overseer and two Hereford bulls are the only Department stock kept on this reserve; the bulls are wintered by the Indians. The overseer has a cow which is his personal property.

Sir,

John Smith's Reserve,

I visited this reserve on Friday, 4th, October, I was no more fortunate herethan I was at Jas. Smith's Reserve. I found the school closed and the teacher away in Prince Albert. Mr. J.H. Gentleman is the teacher. He also acts in the capacity of Overseer of the reserve, which I think is a great mistake, as he is not qualified to fill such a position. If there ever was a reserve that required competent and constant oversight, it seems to me this is one. The Indians here are capable of doing good work, judging from the class of men I saw, but what they need is advice and someone to lead them and this they have not got. To me it looked as if the Indians were living under better conditions years ago, as I saw quite a number of commodious houses that were not kept up and what appeared to be good fields which were allowed to go back. There is no doubt in my mind that if we are to get results from the present day Indians, we must be prepared to furnish competent oversight, men who will lead them and take the same interest in them and their farms, that they would if they were managing their own personal property. I know it is hard to get the right kind of men for the inducements we have to offer. Foremen looking after one section farms situated in white communities, with all the advantages in the way of schools, etc., are getting from $1200.00 to $1500.00 per year, in addition to house, fuel, light, and other perquisites such as food, etc. This being the case you can readily understand that good men will isolate themselves and their families for the wages we are offering. It is true that the class of men we have on many of the Reserves, are not worth more than we are giving them, but it is just this class of man that is holding up the work. All success depends on their leadership.

W. M. Graham,
Commissioner.

SASKATCHEWAN

REMARKS.

ATTENDANCE is not nearly as good as it used to be. Since the Dept. allowed one man to take his girl away the parents have the idea that they can do more or less as they please in the matter. When enquiry is made for absent children the stock answer seems to be that the child is sick or has to work. But sick children are taken to funerals and dances and there is no means of having attendance enforced. As they now kill and sell their cattle just as they like, as well as hay and grain, these things react on the school. The attendance could be improved by having Saskatchewan police visit all houses once a quarter, same as is done in white and halfbreed schools, on request of trustees and in this case Dept. stand as trustees. Apparently the Department wants me to be truant officer. Having called attention to attendance, would consider that it is up to someone higher than I to deal with Indians on the matter. As it is at present they merely think it is an idea of mine when I tell them they should attend better and it does not matter anyway. The people do just as they please and laugh at the Department for being so simple.

P. H. Gentleman

Teacher.

Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 4th inst regarding school attendance, I have had some additional details given me with respect to Frances Jane Mary Bear, which I would like you to place before the Department.

Her father Robbie Bear #97, tells me that this girl was sent to work at the Empress Hotel in Prince Albert, without his knowledge, and very much against his wishes. I asked him by whom "and he supposed "the Crains." I wanted to find out if it had been the action of Mrs. Colin Bear (Sophia Crain) but I do not think he knew. He then told me that he wanted her back at school, but did not know how to act, as the girl had likely hired for a month at the hotel. So I told him that I would write you on the subject as soon as possible.

In the past I have often told this man that he should have his girl to live with him for short periods during the year, but she has always been at the Chas. Crains. I now understand that the girl was "given" to Sophia by her sister Mrs. Robbie Bear (nee Laura Crain) but her Father has never consented to this entirely, that is he has allowed the child to live at the Crains, but would have liked her at home, and I know he always supported the child with clothes. The man, as you know, is somewhat of a quiet disposition, and the Crain family seemed to have taken an advantage of this.

I am of the opinion that James Crain is at the bottom of the whole matter, and perhaps the Department will see how that this man defies all order, event to the extent of taking no notice of the Father of this girl.

I would like to see the Department look into the arrangement of Frances always living at the Chas Crain, and if necessary issue instructions that she should live at her Fathers six months of the year.

At present Robbie Bear is somewhat concerned over his girl, owing to Henry Bears girl Rose, who also worked at the Empress Hotel having married a man three times her age, after an acquaintance-ship of a very few days.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

In making up the annual school report for 1918, that the Dept. ask for direct mail and mailed today, I find it is again necessary to call attention to indifferent attendance, and I would be glad if you would reopen at once the question of a truant officer.

This poor attendance continues, and I am convinced that there is a certain amount of "don't have to" idea among parents, and there is a lack of authority to show otherwise. I spent a recent Saturday looking for children, and met with various excuses, cold, lack of shoes, waiting on sick people, as in the case of Mrs. Albert Smith, whom the Doctor says there is nothing the matter with, but who has to keep a child home to wait upon her.

It is difficult to deal with these matters alone. Doubtless at times such reasons are good, but I am afraid, some of the parents make little effort to overcome them, and are satisfied to dig up some passable excuse, and just let it go at that, as they see that little can be done on our part.

Instances of this nature have recently come to my notice. Most of the children have had bad coughs lately, the Alfred Smith's girl began coughing badly in school. We gave the child several doses of cough mixture and also a large bottle to take home. Absent the following day, but the next day I had to bury the child of Gilbert Crain, and Mrs. Alfred Smith took her girl along to the churchyard and spent most of the afternoon in and out of the church. Colds or coughs wont prevent parents taking children to funerals or dances, and it is just a loss of cough syrup. On the other hand, if they "had to attend," they might make an effort to get them better.

Blacksmith's wife called last week early in the morning saying both her boys were sick, one of school age. Provided with cough syrup and mustard, and pills that seemed necessary, and told to go home and put the children to bed. Appears to have spent most of the day visiting, and the boy of school age who certainly had a very bad cold, had to be sent to look for his mother by Blacksmith who was nursing the youngest child. Samuel, the child in this case who should be at school has got very little attention from his mother.

George Crains Alex, boy of 12 or 13; attendance very bad indeed. Father being sick, boy is made to work, not only doing their own chores, but draws hay from across the river for other people. No reason whatever why this boy should not do all the chores around their own home, and get to school by ten o'clock. Since Jan. 1st 6 days out of 40 in this case.

Frances Jane Mary Bear, sent by her Aunt, or Chas. Crains people to work at Empress Hotel in Prince Albert. Girl of about 14, just in the middle of 6th reader, and taken away in the middle of the quarter, which I very much object to. I had told this people that Francis should finish the reader, and leave at the end of the quarter, and they seem to be willing enough to recognize this at the time, but without saying a word the child is sent to work, and there is no reason; they are not hard up, the girl is too young to work, and hotels are not suitable places.

Henry Bears Terrance, boy of 13. In this case I surmise that Henry has to let the boy have his own way. Henry does not admit this, and speaks of having hay from across the river to draw, but Master Terrance is inclined to want his own way, and having found out that there is nothing to compel attendance, does as he likes.
All these cases might suddenly take a notice to attend again, and in any case, it makes broken classes, and repeated work in school, and repeated work is not fair to those who do attend.

From these instances perhaps the Dept. can gather some of the difficulties that I have to contend with, and I maintain that it is difficult for myself to compel a satisfactory attendance without an independent authority coming from the Dept., as law. A member of the band as truant officer would not be satisfactory, and an arrangement should be arrived at with the Saskatchewan Police to handle the subject in the same manner as is done with white rural schools which our Indians are fully aware of. A standing request with the C.C Prince Albert for a constable to go through the Reserve twice a year to take the names of children not at school, visiting every house, is all that is necessary. Reports of non-attendance could be asked for, but I am convinced that a warning of this kind would have a very desirable effect; in fact I doubt if it would have to be repeated twice. If this could be arranged I feel sure that sick children would have a little more attention, and the "don't have to idea" towards leaving age, would not be so manifest.

At the present time I can do little myself to overcome this difficulty, as the parents take the stand that it is just an idea of mine, and as long as they can find a reasonable excuse, they make little effort. By showing them in this manner that a better attendance is required it would save me a great deal of unpleasant and unsatisfactory work, and be of vast benefit to the Dept. in the future.

Yours truly,

Sgd. P.H. Gentlemen.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

With reference to Mr. Commissioner Graham's letter of the 26th ultimo enclosing a letter received from Mr. Agent Schmidt with regard to the appointment of a truant officer on the John Smith's Reserve I beg to say that the irregular attendance at this school was brought to the Department's attention by Mr. Gentleman, the teacher, in July last, and the Agent was asked, on the 27th of that month, to be good enough to state the name of an Indian who would be suitable for the position of truant officer and also what remuneration he would expect for the work, his duties to commence on the re-opening of the school after the summer holidays. No reply was received from Mr. Schmidt until the receipt of his letter of the 19th ultimo, forwarded under cover of the Commissioner's letter. The Department had no intimation as to what had been done in regard to carrying out these instructions.

Mr. Schmidt states that he took the matter up with Mr. Gentleman last summer, but that he would not hear of having a truant officer on the reserve and, with the regard to the appointment of one now, the Agent does not consider that the same is necessary. Mr. Schmidt also states that if Mr. and Mrs. Gentleman exerted themselves more he is satisfied that the attendance would improve. The Regulations provide for the appointment of a truant officer, and the teacher is not expected to act in that capacity.

Mr. Schmidt, in the concluding paragraph of his letter, says "I consider Mr. Gentleman's usefulness, which never was great, finished on this reserve, and I recommend that a change be made of teacher and overseer, and that a practical and competent person be appointed".

The Commissioner, in his letter, states that the question of schools on this reserve is a farce and that he has already reported fully on this matter. If he has done so I fail to find his reports on the school file.

Mr. Graham agrees with Mr. Schmidt that a truant officer would not be of any advantage, and his recommendation is that the school be closed and that an industrial school be built by the Anglican Church in the city of Prince Albert. He also concurs in Mr. Schmidt's estimate of Mr. Gentleman, and is not the man to be working with the Indians, as far as he can see.

We have only had one report on this school from Mr. Inspector Crombie, which was made in June, 1917, nearly two years ago. While he considered that the progress of the pupils was not as good as might be expected under a teacher who had been in charge as long as Mr. Gentleman, he stated...
stated that the pupils in the higher grades were doing well. A lack of progress was noted in the lower grades. I would be loathe to condemn Mr. Gentleman on any of the reports received on his work.

The trouble with Mr. Gentleman seems to be that he and the Agent have failed to get on together.

Mr. Inspector Crombie, who was asked for a special report in regard to a change of teacher, states that in his opinion the reason for the request made by the Indians is that there is more objection to Mr. Gentleman as overseer on the reserve than as teacher. He says that there are several factions amongst the Indians, part of whom are loyal to the overseer while those who consider they have a grievance against him most doubt signed the petition. The Inspector states that he considers Mr. Gentleman conscientious and trying to do his best for the Indians. He is, however, most unfortunate in that he appears to have the faculty of "getting in wrong" and the Agent has had considerable trouble with him over matters pertaining to the reserve. Mr. Gentleman is positive in his views, and at times makes unreasonable criticisms of the Agent, the Agency and Departmental methods. Mr. Crombie's letter by saying that of late there does not appear to have been the same trouble in this respect, but, taking everything into consideration, he considers that it would be in the interests of the Department if Mr. Gentleman could be transferred to some other school, where he could devote his whole time to the school work.

The Inspector also states that Mrs. Gentleman appears to be rendering good service as matron on this reserve, and her work appears to be appreciated by the members of the Band.

An Indian named James Crain, one of the chief movers for the dismissal of Mr. Gentleman, was written to and told that from information received the Department is of the opinion that some of the Indians on the reserve have failed to give Mr. Gentleman any encouragement or assistance in his work; and that it is hoped that this constant fault finding with the teacher would cease, and that the Department is not prepared to accede to their request.

My experience is that that few, if any, teachers can remain for any length of time on an Indian reserve and avoid trouble, as they are uncertain, coy and hard to please.

In my opinion there are not sufficient grounds to call for Mr. Gentleman's dismissal, but, if he could be given another field, it might be in the best interests of all concerned.

The Commissioner recommends that the school be closed and an industrial school built by the Anglican church in the city of Prince Albert. This is hardly feasible, as the Anglican Church have no funds available for this purpose and the Department has gone to considerable expense by providing suitable day school accommodation. Judging by the photographs of the buildings Mr. Gentleman has kept them in good condition, and there is no reason why a day school there should not be a success.

Dear Sir;

Your letter of June 23rd No 117084-14 14-99 regarding the Overseership of the reserve, and the suggestion that I should seek other employment respecting the school is before me.

In reply I would say that for the past two years and upward I have been made fully aware that Messrs Graham, Crombie and Schmidt have not agreed with my position here, and have placed every possible difficulty in my carrying out my work, and it appears clear that they have at last prevailed upon the Department to endeavour to have a change made.

I will not enter into the merits of my work among these people, for unless the Department could obtain an unbiased report by a competent authority, nothing would be gained.

Regarding the school work, it is of course within some means of the Department to decide if same has been a success, but I cannot refrain from pointing out that the school has not been inspected by a proper school Inspector since Mr W.J. Chisholm left.

However, I may also say that I have just returned from a visit to Archdeacon Tims at the Sarcee, who very much wishes me to take charge of the Old Sun school at the Blackfoot, and I left him on Friday on the understanding that as soon I could decide upon giving up this position he would communicate with Canon Gould of the M.S.C.C. asking for my appointment to be made to the M.S.C.C. staff. Archdeacon Tims has been in correspondence with me for eighteen months regarding the Old Sun, and it has been largely out of respect for the Bishop of Saskatchewan that I have carried on my present school so long as this.

I do not feel however that the Department have any great grounds in seeking my dismissal from the school work, and under the circumstances I feel that I can ask for a transfer.
to the Old Sun school. I would ask the Department to continue my salary here as schoolteacher at $50.00 monthly for the holidays which I am entitled to, July and August, and also an additional allowance of $50.00 towards a car from Prince Albert to Gleichen, which I may say is in the neighbourhood of $95.00.

I visited Old Sun with Archdeacon Tims, also his own school. I went carefully into the details of the management and carrying on of these schools in every possible way. The children at these schools are far behind in their school work compared with the pupils here, and I feel that I could fully come up to the Department's needs as well as the M.S.C.C.

I also had the pleasure of meeting Mr Gordon, and I was given to understand by Canon Stocken that Mr Gooderham, the Blackfoot Agent gives every assistance towards the successful carrying on the schoolwork of his Agency, which are points that make a vast difference to ones work.

I would ask for a communication by return, for after seven years among the Indians, outside of the Hudson Bay Co, the field is limited somewhat, in which I could seek employment, in which I could reap any benefits of my experience among the Indian people.

Trusting the Department may be able to give me this consideration.

Sirs:

For a period of six years from July 1913 - 1919 I was employed by the Indian Dept. at John Smith's Reserve, Prince Albert, Sask., as Overseer and Teacher with my wife as matron of the reserve, under the direction of Mr. C. P. Schmidt, Indian Agent at Duck Lake.

In July last the Indian Dept. informed me that conditions had rendered it unnecessary for me to continue in that position, also that my school was not considered satisfactory and that I had better seek other employment.

I wish to know upon whose recommendation my dismissal was made. I have correspondence from the Indian Dept. not six months old that they were well satisfied with the children under my direction on the occasion of their gaining several prizes at the Prince Albert Fair judged by Provincial School Inspectors in competition with white schools, and the Indian Dept. cannot form any charge against my work in any shape or form which cannot be accounted for, a statement which will be supported on my behalf by W. Know, M. P. for Prince Albert, also the Bishop of Saskatchewan.

For some time past I have been made fully aware by Agent C. P. Schmidt, Inspector Crombie, as well as Commissioner Graham.
Graham that they have personally objected to my work and have placed every difficulty in my way. Agent C. P. Schmidt, a German half-breed has made himself particularly objectionable, and I can place direct charges of many occasions of neglect of his duties that has been the cause of a great deal of trouble among the Indians, also considerable expense to the Indian Department.

The Indian Dept. have agreed to pay the expenses of our move to this school, an Indian Boarding School, but I would like to point out that the salary in my last position came altogether to $1700.00 including that of my wife. This position while carrying with it greater responsibility holds a salary of $600.00 under the arrangements with the Church for the Indian Dept. to pay the grant for the children.

I therefore wish to know, how it is that a man who has put in six years faithful work, who unlike the higher officials of the Indian Dept. has not occupied his time with farms of their own, is liable to treatment of this kind, and in support of my statement of faithful work I can refer to Mr. Knox, the Bishop of Saskatchewan, Professor Bate, any business man in Prince Albert, or any farmer within a radius of ten miles of John Smith's Reserve.

Yours truly,

(SGD) P. W. Gentleman.

Sir,

Regarding my recent letter respecting my removal by the Indian Department from the John Smith's School in Saskatchewan to this establishment, I may inform you that I have now been able to look over the work of these children, and I find that the statement of the Indian Department in their letter No 117084-14 of June 23rd last that my services as a teacher are not satisfactory simply has no grounds whatever to stand upon, when it comes to compare the work of these children with those whom I have just taught.

The state of this schoolroom is simply a disgrace to the Government of Canada. I find that big boys sixteen and seventeen years of age who have been in the school for upward of ten years or more, are only reading out of the second reader, and cannot do a simple multiplication sum. Pen and Ink appears never to have been used. They can copy a piece of writing out of a readingbook onto a slate, but they cannot take a piece of dictation of any kind. These children have boarded here, and have just been neglected, and if any Inspector had come into this place and found fault, there might have been grounds, and I would just like to have Mr Inspector Crombie come along here and compare the two places, for as that party inspected the John Smith's School, it would give me the greatest pleasure to ask him his grounds for fault finding and have the work of the two schools compared. The schoolroom is small, and twelve seats out of thirty broken.

In addition to the neglected state of the schoolroom work, as I intimated in my letter, the whole building, and outfit is about

the most difficult to adopt oneself to schoolwork that I have ever seen in the course of fifteen years of school work. An open drain runs down the middle of the yard into which is placed the contents of three outside closets, not 12 yards from the back door, and this under the nose of the Indian Departments Commissioner, Inspector and Agent.

I am well aware of the fact that this is a Church Mission school, for which the Church is responsible, and that a good deal of the neglect will doubtless be laid upon the church, but there is no getting away from the fact that the Government of Canada are breaking their treaty obligations with the Indians by not giving a grant large enough to carry on the church schools as they should be carried on. If this establishment, and the Roman Catholic School on the Peigan reserve closed up, the Indian Dept/ would either have to open up on their own, or start a Dayschool which would cost them a great deal more than the Educational work among these people is now doing.

However to refer again to our removal from the John Smiths School. Indian Department letters No 117684/1 Aug 29th, 1918 also No 281922 Oct 15th, 1918 both lead me to believe that they are well satisfied with the progress of those children, when their work gained prizes judged by the Provincial Inspectors, who at least are school teachers and know their work, and not Political wire pullers, and I fail entirely to see how the Indian Department could change their attitude within so short a time, unless it is that Messrs Graham, Crombie and Schmidt have taken a great dislike to myself for the simple reason that I endeavored to get them to carry out the Indian Act, and regulations which the Department speak of in their letters.
It seems clear to my mind that I have been made a victim of some kind of humbug, and it is my intention to get to the bottom of it.

I have given nearly seven years satisfaction in my old work, and if the Government will employ rascals like Schmidt, who when appointed Indian Agent had to ask me what the Indian Department meant by the word "Surname" at the top of bond, there is no reason why they should have the power to dismiss a man on personal grounds alone.

I have had a nice home; certainly Indian Department buildings, but I kept them well in repair at my own expense. My total salary was $1700, and I gave my whole attention to my work.

Without any grounds whatever, Messrs Graham, Crombie & Schmidt, all three of them Political appointees, and only Graham with more experience with Indians than I have had, have handed me something so that I have had to take $600 a year, move into a dirty unsuitable home in a disgraceful condition, destroy my two pet animals, and have my household goods smashed up in the transfer.

Such is the treatment the Government of Canada can hand out to a man who has given them seven years straight honest endeavour.

No.7. As to Mr. Graham's suggestion for John Smith's Reserve, to remove the boys and appoint a married farm instructor and a woman teacher, I am writing to him that I greatly depurate it, at least for the present. Sir,

I am writing you in affairs concerning John Smith's School.

When I was transferred from James Smith's reserve to here, I was led to understand by the Bishop, that I was to be in the same position as the previous teacher, that was teacher and overseer. Perhaps I was not told verbally but I inferred so.

I had been here about six weeks when I received your letter which said that the Dept. did not consider the combined position to be advisable.

I am quite satisfied that it is not advisable, and from my own opinion it is advisable to have a farm instructor here too.

The reason I am writing to you is to ask if you would transfer me back to my old position at South Port a la Boine.

The reason is this: During the time of the Rev. Mr. Dougal and Mr. Glattman, the Dept. furnished hay, oats, for the horses, and rations for the employees, which were supposed to be fed to the school and family and also for the overseer.

The rations have been dropped off; I have to buy my own hay and oats, and $140 has been disallowed. The Dept. paying me $5.00 per month.

I have had to pay fifteen dollars per load for hay, till today, and I have got to pay from twenty-five to thirty dollars a load for hay tomorrow. That is, if it's possible to get it, I do not expect to get any at all.

Now it is not possible for a man to do this and live reasonably on the money the Dept. pays for Teacher and Field Matron. It is necessary for anyone who lives so far away from town to keep horses and one cow.

The Indians have been spoiled by previous teachers who have given them quite a lot of goods, and have spent a good sum of money on them in the way of presents until these Indians have become greedy and unreasonable. I do not believe in doing this, as it does not tend to make the Indian the best he can be. I can give an example.

This writer the minister, who makes a journey from Prince Albert every Sunday, was being paid by the Indians fifteen dollars per month towards his stipend and then they charge him fifteen dollars for his hay.

I have tried to make them see that it is only fair that they should let me have the hay at reasonable price, but when refused to pay fifteen dollars for a poor load of hay, they took it away.

I could do better at James Smith's even if I do have to put up with poor condition of house and water, but how can a man live reasonable and pay this price for hay.
I would like to go back to the James Smith's Reserve, as I always had a good attendance and feel that they appreciate the teacher and school more than here. They do not want me to go from there, and asked me to show how I could to get the school open again. But you know the reason I wanted to leave and that was because of the poor conditions. If you think it desirable I would like to go back for the spring.

I remain

Your obedient servant,

March 4th, 1920

Dear Sir;

In 1918 in order to get around the John Smith's reserve quicker I purchased a roadster Mitchell car, which on the first of August last I left in Prince Albert to be sold.

In December I found that the party I left the machine with had disposed of his garage, and the man who took it over sent me a bill for $70.00 for storage, which I have had to pay. I endeavored to sell the outfit at Prince Albert, also to have it stored, but was not successful, and had had to have the machine shipped down to me, and I have now a freight bill of $100.00 to pay, making a total account of $170.00. I feel this is pretty hard, and I would like to know if you can grant me something towards the freight. The fellow I left it with gave me no notice of his intention of leaving Prince Albert; I could not dispose of it and I did not want to give it away. I used it round John Smith's and supplied my own gasoline, and as this place has no rig at all it will be useful to go into town with.

I might add that to keep my transportation costs as low as possible I disposed at a loss more than half of our household goods and with the cost of our move from the Pelicans, and replacing many things, and this account will finish my savings over $300.00.

Taking in all things into consideration, I think something might be done, and I hope you will be able to give it your best consideration.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
